cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 001. Intestate Succession
cards.backPlain: Intestate succession involves the distribution of a decedent's assets that are not disposed of by will. 1. When intestate succession issues arise: 1.1. The decedent dies without a will. 1.2. The decedent's will does not dispose of all of her property (for example, a gift in the will fails or the will lacks a residuary clause). 1.3. The decedent's will is denied probate (for example, the will is successfully contested or improperly executed). 2. Varying statutory schemes: 2.1. States have varying rules for how a decedent's assets are distributed through intestate succession (i.e., who is entitled to the assets and in what amounts). 2.2. Because of this variation, exam questions involving intestate distribution often provide the text of a hypothetical statute governing asset distribution. 3. Terminology: 3.1. Heir vs. beneficiary: An heir is one who takes by intestate succession; a beneficiary is one named in a will or trust. 3.2. Issue and descendants: These terms are often used interchangeably to describe heirs or lineal descendants of the decedent. 3.3. Devise and bequest: These terms are used interchangeably to refer to property disposed of via a will. 3.4. Probate estate: Roughly refers to property the decedent owned upon death that passes through probate.

cards.easyContent: Intestate succession governs how a decedent’s property that is not disposed of by a valid will passes to heirs, usually under a state statute. It applies when there is no will, the will doesn’t cover all property, or the will is denied probate.
cards.mediumContent: Intestate succession is the statutory scheme for distributing a decedent’s assets not disposed of by will, such as when there is no will, when gifts fail or there is no residuary clause, or when the will is denied probate due to contest or improper execution. States vary in how they allocate assets, so exam questions often provide a specific intestacy statute. Key terms: an heir takes by intestacy; a beneficiary is named in a will or trust; issue or descendants are the decedent’s lineal descendants; devise or bequest describe transfers by will; and the probate estate is the property owned at death that passes through probate.
cards.hardContent: Intestate succession governs distribution of a decedent’s assets that are not disposed of by a valid will. Issues arise when the decedent dies without a will, when the will fails to dispose of all property (e.g., failed gift or lack of a residuary clause), or when the will is denied probate because it is successfully contested or improperly executed. Because intestacy rules differ across jurisdictions, bar exam questions commonly provide the text of a hypothetical intestacy statute specifying which relatives take and in what shares. Terminology is critical: an heir is someone who takes by intestate succession, whereas a beneficiary is named in a will or trust. The terms “issue” and “descendants” generally refer to the decedent’s lineal descendants and are often used interchangeably. “Devise” and “bequest” refer to testamentary transfers under a will. The “probate estate” consists roughly of the property the decedent owned at death that must pass through probate rather than by non‑probate mechanisms such as joint tenancy or beneficiary designations.
cards.mnemonic: Remember "H-BID P": Heir, Beneficiary, Issue/Descendants, Devise/Bequest, Probate estate—core intestacy vocabulary.
cards.clozeLite: Intestate succession is the {{c1::statutory scheme}} for assets {{c2::not disposed of by will}}. An {{c3::heir}} takes by intestacy; a {{c4::beneficiary}} is named in a will or trust; the {{c5::probate estate}} passes through probate.

cards.topic: Intestate Share of Surviving Spouse and Children
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 002. Intestate Share of Surviving Spouse and Children
cards.front: Intestate Share of Surviving Spouse and Children – Overview
cards.backPlain: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, the surviving spouse’s share depends on the family configuration. The spouse generally takes the entire estate when there are only shared descendants (and the spouse has no other issue) or when the spouse is the only close survivor (no descendants or parents). In other configurations, the spouse receives a fixed dollar amount plus a fraction of the remaining estate, with specific amounts and fractions varying depending on whether the decedent leaves parents, only shared descendants but the spouse has separate issue, or non-spousal descendants. If there are no qualified heirs at all, the estate escheats to the state.
cards.frontPrompt: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, how does the surviving spouse’s share vary at a high level across different family configurations, and what happens if there are no heirs?
cards.cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, the {{c2::surviving spouse’s share}} depends on the {{c3::family configuration}}. The spouse generally takes {{c4::the entire estate}} when there are only {{c5::shared descendants (and the spouse has no other issue)}} or when the spouse is {{c6::the only close survivor (no descendants or parents)}}. If there are {{c12::no heirs at all}}, the estate {{c13::escheats to the state}}.
cards.easyContent: Under a UPC-style intestacy scheme, a surviving spouse either takes the whole estate (if only shared descendants or just the spouse survive) or gets a fixed dollar amount plus a share of the remaining estate when parents or non-shared descendants also survive; if there are no heirs, the estate escheats to the state.
cards.mediumContent: In a typical UPC intestacy system, the surviving spouse’s share is keyed to the family make-up. The spouse takes the entire estate if (1) the only descendants are shared with the spouse and the spouse has no other issue, or (2) the spouse is the only close survivor (no descendants or parents). In all other major configurations, the spouse receives a fixed dollar amount plus a percentage of the remainder, with different amounts and fractions if the decedent is survived by (a) a parent but no descendants, (b) shared descendants and the spouse’s separate issue, or (c) non-spousal descendants. If no heirs qualify at all, the estate escheats to the state.
cards.hardContent: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, the surviving spouse’s share is structured by family configuration. The spouse generally takes everything where there are (1) only descendants who are also descendants of the spouse and the spouse has no other descendants, or (2) no descendants or parents at all, so only the spouse survives. When additional relatives survive—parents, non-shared issue of the spouse, or non-spousal descendants—the spouse instead receives a fixed dollar amount plus a fraction of the remaining estate, with specific amounts and shares calibrated to each configuration. If the decedent leaves no qualifying heirs whatsoever, the intestate estate escheats to the state.

cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 003. Who Qualifies as Issue?
cards.backPlain: Issue are the decedent's lineal descendants (i.e., children, grandchildren, etc.). There must be a legally recognized parent-child relationship. 1. Adoption and effect on natural parents 1.1. Adoption generally severs the child's inheritance relationship with the natural parents and substitutes the adoptive parents. 1.2. Stepparent adoption creates a parent-child relationship between the child and the stepparent for purposes of inheritance. 1.3. In a typical stepparent adoption, adoption will not prevent the adoptee from inheriting from the other genetic parent who is not the one being replaced by the stepparent. 2. Posthumously born children 2.1. A posthumously born child is conceived before, but born after, the death of the mother's husband. 2.2. If the child is born within 280 days of the husband's death, there is a rebuttable presumption that the child is the husband's and the child will inherit as if born before the husband's death. 2.3. Under the Uniform Parentage Act, this presumption period is extended to 300 days.

cards.easyContent: Issue are the decedent’s lineal descendants, and there must be a legally recognized parent-child relationship. Adoption, stepparent adoption, and rules on posthumously born children determine whether such a relationship exists for inheritance.
cards.mediumContent: Issue means the decedent’s lineal descendants (children, grandchildren, etc.) where a valid parent-child relationship exists. Adoption usually cuts off inheritance through natural parents and substitutes adoptive parents, but stepparent adoption typically preserves inheritance from the other genetic parent. A child conceived before but born after the husband’s death is presumed his child if born within 280 days (300 days under the Uniform Parentage Act), and thus inherits as if born during his life.
cards.hardContent: Issue are the decedent's lineal descendants (children, grandchildren, etc.), and a legally recognized parent-child relationship is required for intestate succession. Adoption generally severs the child’s inheritance rights through the natural parents and creates them through the adoptive parents. In a stepparent adoption, a new inheritance relationship is created between child and stepparent, but the adoptee usually still inherits from the other genetic parent who is not replaced. Posthumously born children—those conceived before but born after the husband’s death—are presumed to be the husband’s issue if born within 280 days of his death (extended to 300 days by the Uniform Parentage Act), so they inherit as if born before his death.

cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 004. Per Capita Intestate Distributions
cards.backPlain: When a decedent's estate does not pass to a surviving spouse, but instead to descendants, intestacy statutes control how distributions are made. States vary, but generally use one of the two approaches below. 1. Per capita with representation (modern per stirpes, majority rule) 1.1. The estate is divided into equal shares at the first generation at which there are living takers. 1.2. Each living person at that level takes one share. 1.3. Each share of a deceased person at that level passes by representation to that person's descendants. 1.4. Example: X dies intestate and has three children, A, B, and C. Only A is alive at X's death (B and C predecease X). A has one child, J. B is survived by one child, K. C is survived by three children, L, M, and N. X's estate is divided into three equal shares: A takes one share; B's share goes to K; L, M, and N split C's share (i.e., L, M, and N each get one-third of C's one-third share). 2. Per capita at each generation (UPC and a growing number of states) 2.1. The estate is divided into equal shares at the first generation with living takers, as above. 2.2. However, the shares that would have gone to deceased persons at that level are combined into a pool. 2.3. That combined pool is divided equally among all takers at the next generation. 2.4. This avoids situations where takers are penalized for having a larger family. 2.5. Example: Using the same scenario above, A still takes one-third, but the remaining two-thirds (representing B and C's shares) is combined and divided equally among B and C's surviving children, K, L, M, and N. Thus, K, L, M, and N each receive one-fourth of the remaining two-thirds.

cards.easyContent: When an estate passes to descendants, states usually use either per capita with representation (modern per stirpes) or per capita at each generation. Both divide at the first generation with living takers, but per capita at each generation pools the deceased shares and divides them equally among all takers at the next level.
cards.mediumContent: In intestate succession to descendants, per capita with representation (modern per stirpes, majority rule) divides the estate at the first generation with living takers; each living person there takes a share, and each deceased person’s share passes by representation down their line. Per capita at each generation (UPC) also divides first at the level with living takers, but then combines the shares of all deceased persons at that level into a pool and divides that pool equally among all takers at the next generation, avoiding penalizing larger families.
cards.hardContent: If a decedent’s estate passes to descendants, intestacy statutes control. Under per capita with representation (modern per stirpes, the majority rule), the estate is divided into equal shares at the first generation with living takers; each living person at that level takes one share, and each deceased person’s share passes by representation to that person’s descendants. Under per capita at each generation (UPC and a growing number of states), the estate is also divided at the first generation with living takers, but the shares for deceased persons at that level are pooled and then divided equally among all takers in the next generation, so descendants of different branches at the same generational level receive equal amounts.
cards.mnemonic: POOL then POUR for per capita at each generation—pool deceased shares, pour equally to next gen.
cards.clozeLite: In intestacy, {{c1::per capita with representation}} divides at first living takers and passes {{c2::each deceased’s share by representation}}. {{c3::Per capita at each generation}} instead {{c4::pools deceased shares}} and {{c5::divides the pool equally among all takers at the next generation}}.

cards.topic: Simultaneous Death and Death Caused by Beneficiary
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 005. Simultaneous Death and Death Caused by Beneficiary
cards.front: Simultaneous Death and Death Caused by Beneficiary
cards.backPlain: A person cannot take as an heir or beneficiary unless she survives the decedent. Issues arise where a decedent and heir or beneficiary die at or about the same time. 1. Simultaneous death rules 1.1. Uniform Simultaneous Death Act (USDA) 1.1.1. Property passes as though the beneficiary or heir died before the decedent, unless there is sufficient evidence that the decedent died first. 1.1.2. The USDA applies to distributions of property by any means, including by will, joint tenancy, intestate succession, life insurance, and similar transfers. 1.2. 120-hour rule 1.2.1. A beneficiary or heir is treated as having survived the decedent only if there is clear evidence that she survived the decedent by at least 120 hours (i.e., five days). 2. Death caused by beneficiary or heir (Slayer Rule) 2.1. A person who wrongfully causes the death of a decedent forfeits any interest in the decedent's estate. 2.2. In such a case, property passes as though the killer predeceased the victim.
cards.frontPrompt: How do the Uniform Simultaneous Death Act, the 120-hour rule, and the Slayer Rule affect whether a person is treated as surviving the decedent and can take from the decedent’s estate?
cards.cloze: A person cannot take as an heir or beneficiary unless she {{c1::survives the decedent}}. Issues arise where a decedent and heir or beneficiary die at or about the same time. 1. {{c2::Simultaneous death rules}} 1.1. {{c3::Uniform Simultaneous Death Act (USDA)}} 1.1.1. Property passes as though the beneficiary or heir {{c4::died before the decedent}}, unless there is sufficient evidence that the decedent died first. 1.1.2. The USDA applies to distributions of property by any means, including by {{c5::will, joint tenancy, intestate succession, life insurance}}, and similar transfers. 1.2. {{c6::120-hour rule}} 1.2.1. A beneficiary or heir is treated as having survived the decedent only if there is clear evidence that she survived the decedent by at least {{c7::120 hours (five days)}}. 2. Death caused by beneficiary or heir ({{c8::Slayer Rule}}) 2.1. A person who {{c9::wrongfully causes the death of a decedent}} forfeits any interest in the decedent's estate. 2.2. In such a case, property passes as though the {{c10::killer predeceased the victim}}.
cards.easyContent: An heir or beneficiary must survive the decedent to take. The USDA and 120-hour rule govern unclear simultaneous deaths, and the Slayer Rule bars someone who wrongfully kills the decedent from inheriting, treating them as if they predeceased.
cards.mediumContent: If death order is unclear, the Uniform Simultaneous Death Act generally treats the beneficiary or heir as if they died first, so they do not take, and it applies to transfers by will, joint tenancy, intestacy, and similar devices. Under the 120-hour rule, an heir or beneficiary is deemed to survive only if there is clear evidence they outlived the decedent by at least 120 hours. Separately, under the Slayer Rule, a person who wrongfully causes the decedent’s death forfeits any interest and is treated as though they predeceased the victim.
cards.hardContent: To inherit, a person must survive the decedent. When a decedent and heir or beneficiary die at or about the same time, the Uniform Simultaneous Death Act directs that property pass as though the beneficiary or heir died before the decedent, unless sufficient evidence shows the decedent died first; it applies broadly to transfers by will, joint tenancy, intestate succession, life insurance, and similar mechanisms. Some jurisdictions also apply the 120-hour rule, under which a person is treated as surviving only if there is clear evidence they lived at least 120 hours (five days) longer than the decedent. Separately, under the Slayer Rule, anyone who wrongfully causes the death of the decedent forfeits any interest in the estate, and the property is distributed as if the killer had predeceased the victim.
cards.mnemonic: SIM-120-SLAY: Simultaneous, 120 hours, Slayer predeceases.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::death order is unclear}}, the {{c2::Uniform Simultaneous Death Act}} and {{c3::120-hour rule}} often treat the {{c4::beneficiary as predeceasing}} the decedent, while the {{c5::Slayer Rule}} bars a {{c6::wrongful killer}} from inheriting.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 006. Disclaimers & Advancements
cards.backPlain: 1. Disclaimers 1.1. A person may disclaim an interest that otherwise would pass to them from a decedent or the decedent's estate. 1.2. Requirements (federal tax purposes) 1.2.1. The disclaimer must be in writing. 1.2.2. The disclaimer must be irrevocable. 1.2.3. The disclaimer must be filed within nine months of the decedent's death. 1.2.4. States may impose additional requirements, although most are satisfied by compliance with the federal requirements. 1.3. Effect 1.3.1. The disclaimed interest passes as if the disclaiming party predeceased the decedent. 2. Advancements 2.1. Advancements are gifts made during the testator's or decedent's life with the intent that the gift be applied against any share the heir or beneficiary inherits from the decedent's or testator's estate. 2.2. Common law 2.2.1. Gifts were automatically deducted from the beneficiary's or heir's remaining interest. 2.3. Modern requirement 2.3.1. In most states, a gift to a beneficiary or heir during the testator's or decedent's life is treated as an advancement only if either: 2.3.1.1. The decedent declared her intent to make the gift an advancement in a contemporaneous writing; or 2.3.1.2. The beneficiary or heir acknowledged the gift to be an advancement in writing. 3. Applicability beyond intestacy 3.1. The above rules generally apply to gifts or interests that pass in forms beyond intestacy, such as by will.

cards.easyContent: A person can disclaim an inheritance by a timely written, irrevocable disclaimer, causing the property to pass as if they had predeceased the decedent. Advancements are lifetime gifts intended to count against an heir’s share, and under modern law they are treated as such only with written evidence of that intent.
cards.mediumContent: A disclaimer lets an heir or beneficiary refuse an interest that would otherwise pass to them; for federal tax purposes it must be in writing, irrevocable, and filed within nine months of death, and the disclaimed interest then passes as if the disclaimant had predeceased the decedent. Advancements are lifetime gifts intended to be charged against an heir’s eventual share; at common law such gifts were automatically deducted, but under the modern approach they are treated as advancements only if the decedent’s contemporaneous writing or the heir’s written acknowledgment shows that intent. These concepts generally apply not only in intestacy but also to gifts passing by will and similar instruments.
cards.hardContent: Disclaimers allow a person to refuse an inheritance or other interest that would otherwise pass from a decedent or the decedent’s estate. For federal tax purposes, a valid disclaimer must be in writing, irrevocable, and filed within nine months of the decedent’s death; most state statutes largely track these requirements. A proper disclaimer causes the disclaimed interest to pass as though the disclaimant had predeceased the decedent. Advancements are lifetime gifts made with the intent that they be applied against the recipient’s eventual intestate or testamentary share. At common law, such gifts were automatically deducted from the heir’s or beneficiary’s share. Under the modern rule in most states, a lifetime gift is treated as an advancement only if the decedent contemporaneously declares that intent in writing or the beneficiary/heir acknowledges in writing that the gift is an advancement. These rules typically apply both in intestacy and to transfers under a will.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 007. Wills and Requirements for Execution
cards.backPlain: A will is an instrument that directs the disposition of a person's property when they die. It has no legal effect before the testator's death and becomes operative upon death. A will may be revoked or amended until the testator's death, and named beneficiaries have only an expectancy interest (i.e., no present property rights). 1. Basic execution requirements (formal, attested will) 1.1. In writing. 1.2. Signed by the testator. 1.2.1. Any mark intended to be a signature suffices. 1.2.2. If the testator is incapable of signing, the will must be signed by another person in the testator's presence and at the testator's direction. 1.3. Signed by at least two witnesses. 1.3.1. The witnesses must see the testator sign the will (or acknowledge the signature) and must sign as witnesses within a reasonable time. 1.3.2. The signing must occur in the testator's presence, which many states define by a "line of sight" test, while others use a broader "conscious presence" test. 1.3.3. Under the UPC, the witnesses may sign within a reasonable time after the testator's signature. 1.4. In many states, a licensed notary can satisfy the requirement for witnesses. 2. Attestation clause 2.1. An attestation clause is a clause included immediately between the testator's and witnesses' signatures in a will. 2.2. It sets forth the execution elements above and recites that they were satisfied. 2.3. The attestation clause constitutes prima facie evidence of the facts recited in the clause (i.e., that the execution requirements have been satisfied).

The signing must occur in the testator's presence, which many states define by a {{c8::"line of sight"}} test, while others use a broader {{c9::"conscious presence"}} test. 1.3.3. Under the {{c10::UPC}}, the witnesses may sign within a {{c11::reasonable time}} after the testator's signature. 1.4. In many states, a {{c12::licensed notary}} can satisfy the requirement for witnesses. 2. {{c13::Attestation clause}} 2.1. An attestation clause is a clause included immediately between the testator's and witnesses' signatures in a will. 2.2. It sets forth the execution elements above and recites that they were satisfied. 2.3. The attestation clause constitutes {{c14::prima facie evidence}} of the facts recited in the clause (i.e., that the execution requirements have been satisfied).
cards.easyContent: A will is a revocable instrument that controls the distribution of a person’s property at death and has no effect until the testator dies. A formal will usually must be in writing, signed by the testator, and signed by two witnesses in the testator’s presence, often with an attestation clause to prove proper execution.
cards.mediumContent: A will directs the disposition of a person’s property at death, has no legal effect until the testator dies, and can be revoked or amended up to that point, leaving beneficiaries only an expectancy. A typical formal will must be in writing, signed by the testator (or another at the testator’s direction in the testator’s presence), and signed by at least two witnesses who see the testator sign or acknowledge the will and sign within a reasonable time in the testator’s presence. Presence is often defined by a line-of-sight or conscious-presence test, and many states allow a licensed notary to substitute for witnesses. An attestation clause between the testator’s and witnesses’ signatures recites compliance with these formalities and serves as prima facie evidence that execution requirements were met.
cards.hardContent: A will is an instrument that directs how a person’s property is distributed at death. It is revocable or amendable until the testator’s death, has no legal effect beforehand, and gives named beneficiaries only an expectancy interest. For a formal, attested will, most states require that it be in writing; be signed by the testator (or by another person in the testator’s presence and at their direction); and be signed by at least two witnesses, who see the testator sign or acknowledge the signature and sign within a reasonable time in the testator’s presence. Presence is typically determined by either a line-of-sight or conscious-presence standard, and under the UPC, witnesses may sign within a reasonable time after the testator. Many states allow a licensed notary to satisfy the witness requirement. An attestation clause placed between the testator’s and witnesses’ signatures recites that the execution formalities were followed and is prima facie evidence that the will was duly executed.

cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::will}} is a {{c2::revocable instrument}} controlling property at death, usually requiring {{c3::writing}}, {{c4::testator’s signature}}, and {{c5::two witnesses in presence}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 008. Witness Requirements and Limitations
cards.backPlain: Witnesses to a will must be competent, and in most states there are limitations on witnesses who stand to benefit from the will. 1. Competency 1.1 The witness must have sufficient maturity and mental capacity to understand and appreciate the nature of what they witness and attest to. 1.2 The witness must be capable of sufficiently testifying in court if required. 2. Interested witnesses (a witness who stands to benefit under the will) 2.1 Common law: the entire will could not be probated if there was an interested witness (this rule has been mostly abolished). 2.2 Majority rule: the will is valid, but the gift to the witness-beneficiary is void. 2.3 Exceptions (under the majority approach, an interested witness can still be a beneficiary if either): 2.3.1 There were at least two other disinterested witnesses (i.e., three total witnesses, two of whom were disinterested); or 2.3.2 The interested witness would take if there were no will (i.e., the interested witness would have taken as an heir through intestate succession). In that case, the witness may take the lesser of the intestate share or the bequest. 3. UPC rule 3.1 Under the UPC, the presence of an interested witness does not invalidate the will or any part of it, and the gift to the interested witness is not automatically void.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 009. Testamentary Capacity & Intent Requirements
cards.backPlain: For a will to be valid, the testator must have testamentary capacity and the requisite testamentary intent. Contests over the validity of a will often involve whether the testator had the requisite capacity or intent. 1. Capacity (the person executing the will must be 18 or older and have mental capacity) 1.1 Age is determined at the time the will is executed. 1.2 Mental capacity means that, at the time of execution, the testator understands: 1.2.1 The nature of the act (that they are executing a will). 1.2.2 The nature and extent of their property. 1.2.3 The persons who are the natural objects of their bounty. 1.2.4 How these factors relate to form a coherent plan of distribution. 1.3 There is a rebuttable presumption that the testator had mental capacity. Physical ailments or drug addiction do not, by themselves, create a presumption of incapacity. 2. Testamentary intent (the testator must intend that the instrument operate as their will) 2.1 Testamentary intent is usually established by the provisions and language in the instrument itself. 2.2 Present intent is required: the testator must have present testamentary intent; mere intent to make a will in the future is insufficient. 2.3 Extrinsic evidence is allowed to prove the presence or absence of testamentary intent. At common law, strict compliance with formalities was required; under the UPC, substantial compliance may be sufficient where intent is clear.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for testamentary capacity and testamentary intent for a valid will, and how are they proven?

Contests over the validity of a will often involve whether the testator had the requisite capacity or intent. 1. {{c3::Capacity}} (the person executing the will must be {{c4::18 or older}} and have mental capacity) 1.1 Age is determined at the time the will is {{c5::executed}}. 1.2 Mental capacity means that, at the time of execution, the testator understands: 1.2.1 The {{c6::nature of the act}} (that they are executing a will). 1.2.2 The {{c7::nature and extent of their property}}. 1.2.3 The persons who are the {{c8::natural objects of their bounty}}. 1.2.4 How these factors relate to form a {{c9::coherent plan of distribution}}. 1.3 There is a {{c10::rebuttable presumption}} that the testator had mental capacity. Physical ailments or drug addiction do not, by themselves, create a presumption of incapacity. 2. {{c11::Testamentary intent}} (the testator must intend that the instrument operate as their will) 2.1 Testamentary intent is usually established by the {{c12::provisions and language in the instrument itself}}. 2.2 {{c13::Present}} intent is required: the testator must have present testamentary intent; mere intent to make a will in the {{c14::future}} is insufficient. 2.3 {{c15::Extrinsic evidence}} is allowed to prove the presence or absence of testamentary intent. At common law, {{c16::strict compliance}} with formalities was required; under the UPC, {{c17::substantial compliance}} may be sufficient where intent is clear.
cards.easyContent: A valid will requires that the testator be at least 18, mentally capable of understanding what a will does, what property they have, and who their natural heirs are, and that they presently intend the document to be their will.
cards.mediumContent: Testamentary capacity requires that at execution the testator is at least 18 and understands that they are making a will, the nature and extent of their property, the natural objects of their bounty, and how these fit together into a plan of distribution. There is a rebuttable presumption of capacity, and physical illness or substance use alone does not create a presumption of incapacity. Testamentary intent requires that the testator intends the instrument to operate as their will and has present intent (not merely an intent to make a will later); intent is usually shown from the document and may be supplemented by extrinsic evidence. Common law demanded strict compliance with formalities, while the UPC allows substantial compliance where intent is clear.
cards.hardContent: For a will to be valid, the testator must have both testamentary capacity and testamentary intent. Capacity requires that, at the time of execution, the testator is at least 18 years old and has sufficient mental capacity to understand: (1) that they are executing a will (the nature of the act); (2) the nature and extent of their property; (3) the persons who are the natural objects of their bounty; and (4) how these factors interrelate to form a coherent scheme of distribution. There is a rebuttable presumption that the testator possessed such capacity, and physical ailments or drug addiction, standing alone, do not create a presumption of incapacity. Testamentary intent requires that the testator intend the instrument to operate as their will and have present, not future, testamentary intent. Intent is usually inferred from the language and structure of the instrument itself, but extrinsic evidence is admissible to show the presence or absence of such intent. At common law, strict compliance with will formalities was required; under the UPC, substantial compliance may suffice if the testator’s intent is clearly established.
cards.mnemonic: Capacity A4: Act, Assets, Heirs, Arrangement; plus age 18.
cards.clozeLite: Testamentary {{c1::capacity}} requires 18+ and understanding {{c2::nature of the act}}, {{c3::property}}, {{c4::natural objects of bounty}}, and {{c5::distribution plan}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 010. Codicils and Holographic Wills
cards.backPlain: 1. Codicils (amendments, modifications, or alterations to a previously executed will) 1.1 A codicil must be executed with the same formalities required for a will (e.g., in writing, signed by the testator, and properly witnessed, depending on the jurisdiction). 1.2 When a codicil is validly executed, the original will is treated as republished and is deemed to have been executed on the date the codicil was executed. 2. Holographic wills (handwritten, unwitnessed wills; not recognized in all states) 2.1 Requirements for a valid holographic will 2.1.1 The will must be in the testator's handwriting. Some states require the entire will to be handwritten; others allow some typewritten text so long as the typed portion is not material. Under the UPC, only the material portions must be in the testator's handwriting. 2.1.2 The will must be signed somewhere by the testator. 2.1.3 The document must, as a whole, reflect the testator's intent that it operate as a will. For example, a letter signed by the testator requesting changes to an existing will is not itself a will because it contemplates a future writing that will constitute the will. 2.2 A valid holographic will replaces and revokes any prior valid will to the extent of inconsistency. 2.3 Oral (nuncupative) wills are not permitted in most states.
cards.frontPrompt: What are codicils and holographic wills, and what formal requirements and effects do they have for a valid will?

Some states require the entire will to be handwritten; others allow some typewritten text so long as the typed portion is not material. Under the {{c6::UPC}}, only the {{c7::material portions}} must be in the testator's handwriting. 2.1.2 The will must be {{c8::signed}} somewhere by the testator. 2.1.3 The document must, as a whole, reflect the testator's {{c9::intent that it operate as a will}}. cards.easyContent: A codicil is an amendment to a will that must meet the same formalities as a will and republishes the will as of the codicil date. A holographic will is a handwritten, usually unwitnessed will valid only in some states, requiring the testator’s handwriting, signature, and testamentary intent.
cards.mediumContent: Codicils amend or modify a previously executed will and must satisfy the same formalities as a will (writing, signature, and required witnesses). A validly executed codicil republishes the will as of the codicil date. Holographic wills are handwritten, unwitnessed wills recognized in some jurisdictions; they generally require that the material portions be in the testator’s handwriting (under the UPC), that the testator sign the document, and that the writing as a whole show intent that it operate as a will. A valid holographic will revokes or replaces prior wills to the extent of inconsistency, and oral (nuncupative) wills are not allowed in most states.
cards.hardContent: Codicils are written instruments that amend, modify, or otherwise alter an existing will. To be valid, a codicil must be executed with the same formalities as a will, typically including being in writing, signed by the testator, and witnessed as required by the governing law. A duly executed codicil republishes the original will, causing the will to be deemed executed on the date of the codicil. Holographic wills are handwritten, usually unwitnessed wills recognized only in certain jurisdictions. Their validity generally requires that the document be in the testator’s handwriting (with some states requiring the entire instrument to be handwritten, while the UPC only requires the material portions to be), that it be signed by the testator somewhere on the document, and that the writing, viewed as a whole, demonstrate the testator’s intent that it function as a will rather than a mere note or instruction (e.g., a letter requesting future changes is not itself a will). A valid holographic will revokes or replaces prior wills to the extent inconsistent, and most states do not recognize oral (nuncupative) wills at all.

cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::codicil}} must meet {{c2::will formalities}} and {{c3::republishes the will as of the codicil date}}. A {{c4::holographic will}} is {{c5::handwritten, signed, showing testamentary intent}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 011. Integration
cards.backPlain: Integration issues can arise where part of a will becomes separated (for example, pages of a multipage, stapled will become separated). The issue is whether the separate pages can be integrated and construed as the testator's complete will. 1. Test for integration (a document will be integrated into a will if): 1.1 Physical presence: the document was physically present at the time of the will's execution; and 1.2 Intent of inclusion: the testator intended the document to be part of the will. 2. Evidence: witness testimony and other extrinsic evidence may be used to establish that the requirements for integration have been satisfied. 3. Presumption: the integration requirements are presumed where there is a physical connection of pages (for example, staples or paperclips) or when there is some internal coherence (i.e., the pages, when combined, comprise a complete, orderly disposition).
cards.frontPrompt: When separate pages are found with a will, what is the test for integrating them into the will, and what evidence and presumptions apply?

The issue is whether the separate pages can be {{c2::integrated}} and construed as the testator's complete will. 1. Test for integration (a document will be integrated into a will if): 1.1 {{c3::Physical presence}}: the document was physically present at the time of the will's execution; and 1.2 {{c4::Intent of inclusion}}: the testator intended the document to be part of the will. 2. {{c5::Evidence}}: witness testimony and other {{c6::extrinsic evidence}} may be used to establish that the requirements for integration have been satisfied. 3. {{c7::Presumption}}: the integration requirements are presumed where there is a {{c8::physical connection of pages}} (for example, staples or paperclips) or when there is some {{c9::internal coherence}} (i.e., the pages, when combined, comprise a complete, orderly disposition).
cards.easyContent: Integration determines whether loose or separated pages belong to a will. A page is integrated if it was physically present at execution and the testator intended it to be part of the will.
cards.mediumContent: If part of a will becomes separated, a document may be integrated into the will if it was physically present at execution and the testator intended it to be part of the will. Witness testimony and other extrinsic evidence can prove these elements. Courts presume integration where there is physical connection between pages (like staples or paperclips) or where the pages show internal coherence and form a complete, orderly disposition when read together.
cards.hardContent: Integration addresses whether separated or loose documents form part of a will. A document will be integrated into a will if two elements are satisfied: (1) physical presence—the document was physically present at the time of the will’s execution; and (2) intent of inclusion—the testator intended the document to be part of the will. Witness testimony and other extrinsic evidence may be used to establish these elements. Courts often apply a presumption of integration when there is a physical connection among pages (such as staples, paperclips, or similar fasteners) or when the pages exhibit internal coherence, such that together they constitute a complete, orderly testamentary disposition.

cards.clozeLite: A document is {{c1::integrated into a will}} if it was {{c2::physically present at execution}} and the {{c3::testator intended it to be part of the will}}; courts may {{c4::presume integration from staples or coherent pages}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 012. Acts of Independent Significance
cards.backPlain: A will can dispose of property by reference to acts or events occurring after the testator executes the will. In other words, identification of a beneficiary or the amount or nature of a gift in a will may be determined by some future act or event. Such provisions are valid as long as the act or event has some independent significance during the testator's lifetime other than providing a gift in the will. 1. Identifying beneficiaries 1.1 A future act or event can involve identification of beneficiaries. For example: T's will leaves "$10,000 to each of my gardeners employed at my death." Two years after executing the will, T fires one gardener and hires three others, who remain employed until T dies. The gifts to the gardeners employed at death are valid because it is presumed that T did not hire and fire gardeners solely to change who would benefit under the will; the employment decisions have independent significance. 2. Identifying property 2.1 A future act or event can involve identification of property. For example: T's will leaves "all automobiles I own at my death to A." T owns three cars at the time of execution, later sells one and buys two more before she dies, leaving A with a bequest of the four automobiles T owns at her death. The bequest is valid because it is presumed that T did not buy and sell cars solely to change A's gift; the transactions have independent significance beyond the will.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the doctrine of acts of independent significance in wills, and how does it apply to identifying beneficiaries and property?

In other words, identification of a {{c2::beneficiary}} or the {{c3::amount or nature of a gift}} in a will may be determined by some future act or event. Such provisions are valid as long as the act or event has some {{c4::independent significance}} during the testator's lifetime other than providing a gift in the will. 1. Identifying beneficiaries 1.1 A future act or event can involve identification of beneficiaries. For example: T's will leaves "$10,000 to each of my gardeners employed at my death." Two years after executing the will, T fires one gardener and hires three others, who remain employed until T dies. The gifts to the gardeners employed at death are valid because it is presumed that T did not hire and fire gardeners solely to change who would benefit under the will; the {{c5::employment decisions have independent significance}}. 2. Identifying property 2.1 A future act or event can involve identification of property. For example: T's will leaves "all automobiles I own at my death to A." T owns three cars at the time of execution, later sells one and buys two more before she dies, leaving A with a bequest of the four automobiles T owns at her death. The bequest is valid because it is presumed that T did not buy and sell cars solely to change A's gift; the {{c6::transactions have independent significance}} beyond the will.
cards.easyContent: Under the doctrine of acts of independent significance, a will can refer to future acts or events to determine who takes or what property is given, so long as those acts have a purpose other than changing the will’s gifts.
cards.mediumContent: Acts of independent significance allow a will to dispose of property by reference to acts or events that occur after execution, such as who is employed at death or what property the testator owns then. These provisions are valid if the act or event has some independent, lifetime purpose besides altering testamentary gifts. For example, a gift to "my gardeners employed at my death" is valid because hiring and firing gardeners is presumed to be driven by employment needs, and a gift of "all automobiles I own at my death" is valid because buying and selling cars serves normal personal or business purposes.
cards.hardContent: The doctrine of acts of independent significance permits a will to identify beneficiaries or property by reference to acts or events occurring after execution, so that the ultimate recipients or the subject matter of gifts may change over time without a formal will amendment. The key requirement is that the referenced act or event have significance independent of any intent to alter testamentary dispositions; it must serve a genuine lifetime purpose other than changing who takes under the will. Thus, a bequest of "$10,000 to each of my gardeners employed at my death" is valid even if the testator later fires and hires different gardeners, because employment decisions are presumed to be motivated by ordinary business reasons, not by a desire to manipulate will beneficiaries. Similarly, a gift of "all automobiles I own at my death to A" is valid even though the testator may buy or sell cars after execution, because such transactions are presumed to reflect normal personal or financial choices, not an attempt to adjust A's bequest.

cards.clozeLite: Acts of {{c1::independent significance}} let a will use {{c2::post-execution acts or events}} to identify {{c3::beneficiaries or property}}, if those acts have a {{c4::lifetime purpose beyond changing gifts}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 013. Incorporation by Reference
cards.backPlain: Documents extrinsic to the will (i.e., not physically part of the will) may be incorporated by reference into the will in most states. 1. Requirements (a document will be incorporated by reference where): 1.1 Intent to incorporate: the will manifests the testator's intent to incorporate the document. 1.2 Authenticated document: the will sufficiently describes the document such that it can be authenticated. 1.2.1 The description must be such that the document can be reasonably identified. 1.2.2 The document must correspond to the will's description. 1.3 In existence upon will execution: the document must be in existence at the time the will is executed. 2. Tangible personal property exception: in most states, a will may incorporate by reference a document (i.e., statement or list) that disposes of the testator's tangible personal property. 2.1 The document can be prepared before or after execution of the will and can be changed before the testator's death. 2.2 Requirements: the document must be: 2.2.1 Signed by the testator. 2.2.2 Describe the items and to whom they are devised with reasonable certainty.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for incorporation by reference of an extrinsic document into a will, and what is the special rule for lists disposing of tangible personal property?
cards.cloze: Documents extrinsic to the will (i.e., not physically part of the will) may be {{c1::incorporated by reference}} into the will in most states. 1. Requirements (a document will be incorporated by reference where): 1.1 {{c2::Intent to incorporate}}: the will manifests the testator's intent to incorporate the document. 1.2 {{c3::Authenticated document}}: the will sufficiently describes the document such that it can be authenticated. 1.2.1 The description must be such that the document can be {{c4::reasonably identified}}. 1.2.2 The document must {{c5::correspond to the will's description}}. 1.3 {{c6::In existence upon will execution}}: the document must be in existence at the time the will is executed. 2. {{c7::Tangible personal property exception}}: in most states, a will may incorporate by reference a document (i.e., statement or list) that disposes of the testator's tangible personal property. 2.1 The document can be prepared {{c8::before or after execution of the will}} and can be {{c9::changed before the testator's death}}. 2.2 Requirements: the document must be: 2.2.1 {{c10::Signed by the testator}}. 2.2.2 Describe the items and to whom they are devised with {{c11::reasonable certainty}}.
cards.easyContent: A will can incorporate an extrinsic document by reference if the testator intended to incorporate it, the will adequately describes and thus authenticates it, and the document existed when the will was executed, with a special relaxed rule for signed lists of tangible personal property.
cards.mediumContent: Incorporation by reference allows a will to treat an extrinsic document as if it were part of the will where (1) the will shows intent to incorporate it, (2) the will describes it well enough that it can be authenticated and reasonably identified, and (3) the document existed when the will was executed. Most states also allow a separate, signed list disposing of tangible personal property that can be created or changed before death, so long as the items and recipients are described with reasonable certainty.
cards.hardContent: Documents extrinsic to a will may be incorporated by reference in most states if three requirements are met: (1) the will manifests the testator's intent to incorporate the document; (2) the will sufficiently describes the document so that it can be authenticated, meaning the description allows the document to be reasonably identified and the document corresponds to that description; and (3) the document is in existence at the time the will is executed. As an exception for tangible personal property, most states allow a will to incorporate by reference a separate written statement or list disposing of the testator's tangible personal property; that document may be prepared before or after execution of the will, and may be changed at any time before death, but it must be signed by the testator and must describe the items and the intended recipients with reasonable certainty.
cards.mnemonic: IAD + List: Intent, Adequate description, Document exists, plus signed list for tangibles.
cards.clozeLite: Incorporation by reference needs {{c1::intent to incorporate}}, {{c2::sufficient description to authenticate}}, and {{c3::document in existence at execution}}, plus a {{c4::signed, changeable list for tangible personal property}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 014. Revocation by Testator
cards.backPlain: A person who has testamentary capacity to make a valid will can revoke a will at any time before their death. 1. Revocation by written instrument: a will or any part of it can be revoked or changed as long as there is: 1.1 Intent: present intent to revoke. 1.2 Formalities: the instrument revoking the will is made with the same formalities required for will execution. 2. Revocation by physical act: a will may be revoked in most states by burning, tearing, or otherwise destroying the will. 2.1 Present intent required: the testator must intend to revoke at the time of the physical act. 2.2 Act by another (revocation by proxy): a person other than the testator may revoke the will by physical act if done at the testator's direction and in the testator's presence. 3. Partial revocation: 3.1 Revocation may be accomplished by making marks of cancellation on the will (e.g., crossing out provisions) in most states. 3.2 Where such marks are found on a will known to have last been in the testator's possession, a presumption is created that the marks were made by the testator with the requisite intent to revoke.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a testator revoke a will or part of a will, and what intent and formalities are required, including for revocation by physical act and by proxy?

cards.easyContent: A testator with capacity can revoke a will any time before death, either by a later will or writing executed with will formalities, or by a physical act like burning or tearing done with present intent to revoke.
cards.mediumContent: Revocation by a competent testator can be accomplished (1) by written instrument—a later will or codicil that clearly shows present intent to revoke and is executed with the same formalities as a will, or (2) by physical act—burning, tearing, or otherwise destroying the will with present intent to revoke. Another person may perform the physical act only if it is done at the testator's direction and in the testator's presence. Partial revocation is allowed in most states by cancellation marks on the will, and cancellation marks found on a will last in the testator's possession give rise to a presumption of revocation by the testator.
cards.hardContent: A person with testamentary capacity may revoke a will at any time before death. Revocation by written instrument occurs when a later will or codicil, executed with the same formalities required for will execution, manifests a present intent to revoke all or part of the earlier will. Revocation by physical act occurs when the testator burns, tears, or otherwise destroys the will, or directs someone else to do so in the testator's presence, with present intent to revoke. Most states recognize partial revocation by physical act, such as crossing out or cancelling specific provisions. If cancellation marks appear on a will known to have last been in the testator's possession, a presumption arises that the testator made the marks with the intent to revoke to that extent.

cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::competent testator}} may revoke a will by {{c2::later will or codicil with will formalities}} or by {{c3::physical act (burning, tearing, destroying)}} done with {{c4::present intent to revoke}}; a proxy act must be {{c5::at testator's direction and in testator's presence}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 015. Revocation by Operation of Law
cards.backPlain: A will and/or its provisions can be revoked by operation of law upon the happening of certain events, usually involving changes in marital status or the birth or adoption of children. 1. Marriage following execution of a will (omitted spouse): 1.1 In most states: marriage after execution has no effect on the existing will (i.e., the new spouse remains omitted). 1.2 Under the UPC: where a person marries after executing a will and the spouse survives the testator, the omitted spouse will take a share of the decedent's estate equivalent to what their intestate share would be, unless: 1.2.1 The will provides for the omitted spouse. 1.2.2 The will was made in contemplation of marriage. 1.2.3 The will otherwise makes clear that the omission was intentional. 2. Divorce following execution of a will: 2.1 Revokes all bequests made in favor of the former spouse, unless the will expressly provides otherwise. 2.2 The remainder of the will remains valid. 2.3 Effect: the will is treated as if the former spouse predeceased the testator. 3. Pretermitted children: arises where the testator's will does not provide for children born or adopted after the will was executed. Most states give the pretermitted child a share of the testator's estate equal to what they would have received through intestate succession.
cards.frontPrompt: How do marriage, divorce, and the birth or adoption of children affect a will by operation of law, including omitted spouses and pretermitted children?

Most states give the pretermitted child a share of the testator's estate equal to what they would have received through {{c16::intestate succession}}.
cards.easyContent: Certain life events change a will automatically: divorce generally revokes gifts to a former spouse, many jurisdictions protect children born or adopted after execution as pretermitted children, and under the UPC an omitted later spouse receives an intestate-like share unless the will shows otherwise.
cards.mediumContent: Revocation by operation of law occurs when events such as marriage, divorce, or the birth or adoption of children alter a will without a new instrument. In most states, later marriage alone does not affect an earlier will, but under the UPC an omitted spouse who marries the testator after execution and survives takes a share roughly equal to an intestate share unless the will provides for them, was made in contemplation of marriage, or clearly shows an intentional omission. Divorce generally revokes all bequests to the former spouse and treats them as having predeceased, leaving the rest of the will intact. Pretermitted children—those born or adopted after execution who are not provided for—typically receive what they would have taken under intestacy.
cards.hardContent: A will can be altered by operation of law when specified family changes occur. First, a marriage after execution creates an omitted spouse problem: in most states, the existing will is unaffected and the new spouse remains omitted, but under the UPC the spouse who marries the testator after execution and survives is entitled to a share equal to their intestate share unless (1) the will itself provides for the spouse, (2) the will was made in contemplation of marriage, or (3) the will clearly indicates that failure to provide for the spouse was intentional. Second, divorce or annulment after execution generally revokes all bequests and fiduciary appointments in favor of the former spouse, unless the will expressly preserves them; the rest of the will remains valid, and the former spouse is treated as if they predeceased the testator. Third, pretermitted children—children born or adopted after execution who are not provided for in the will—are usually given a share equal to what they would have received in intestate succession, thereby partially revoking conflicting will provisions by operation of law.
cards.mnemonic: MOD: Marriage omitted spouse, divorce deletes, kids protected.
cards.clozeLite: By operation of law, {{c1::divorce}} generally revokes gifts to a former spouse, {{c2::omitted spouses}} get an intestate-like share, and {{c3::pretermitted children}} take an intestate share.

cards.topic: Reviving Revoked Wills & Dependent Relative Revocation
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 016. Reviving Revoked Wills & Dependent Relative Revocation
cards.front: Reviving Revoked Wills & Dependent Relative Revocation
cards.backPlain: 1. Revival: where a will is revoked and the revoking instrument is subsequently revoked, the original will is presumptively revived. 1.1 Exception: the revoked will is not revived if the testator's statements or other evidence make clear she did not intend to revive the prior will. 1.2 Re-execution: a revoked will may be re-executed by a subsequent will or codicil if testamentary formalities are satisfied. 2. Dependent Relative Revocation (DRR): a court doctrine under which a court disregards a revocation that was done to create an alternative disposition to the original will, but was based on a mistake of fact or law. 2.1 The court will apply DRR and revive the revoked will if doing so would come closer to giving effect to what the testator tried, but failed, to do than would intestate succession. 2.2 Requirements (a court may apply DRR and ignore the revocation where): 2.2.1 The revocation was premised on some mistake of law or fact. 2.2.2 The revocation would not have occurred absent the testator's mistaken belief that some other plan for disposition of property was valid. 2.2.3 The originally revoked will is closer to the testator's preference than would be intestate succession.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a revoked will be revived, and what is the doctrine of dependent relative revocation (DRR) and its requirements?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Revival}}: where a will is revoked and the revoking instrument is subsequently revoked, the original will is {{c2::presumptively revived}}. 1.1 Exception: the revoked will is not revived if the testator's statements or other evidence make clear she {{c3::did not intend to revive}} the prior will. 1.2 {{c4::Re-execution}}: a revoked will may be re-executed by a subsequent will or codicil if {{c5::testamentary formalities}} are satisfied. 2. {{c6::Dependent Relative Revocation}} ({{c7::DRR}}): a court doctrine under which a court {{c8::disregards a revocation}} that was done to create an alternative disposition to the original will, but was based on a {{c9::mistake of fact or law}}. 2.1 The court will apply DRR and revive the revoked will if doing so would come closer to giving effect to what the testator {{c10::tried, but failed, to do}} than would {{c11::intestate succession}}. 2.2 Requirements (a court may apply DRR and ignore the revocation where): 2.2.1 The revocation was premised on some {{c12::mistake of law or fact}}. 2.2.2 The revocation would not have occurred absent the testator's mistaken belief that some {{c13::other plan for disposition}} of property was valid. 2.2.3 The originally revoked will is {{c14::closer to the testator's preference}} than would be intestate succession.
cards.easyContent: A revoked will can be revived if the later revoking instrument is itself revoked and the testator intended the earlier will to come back, and DRR lets a court ignore a revocation based on a mistaken belief that another disposition was valid when reviving the old will better matches the testator’s intent.
cards.mediumContent: Revival occurs when an earlier will is brought back after it was revoked, typically when the later revoking instrument is revoked; many jurisdictions presume revival unless other evidence shows the testator did not intend the prior will to revive, and a revoked will can also be re‑executed by a later will or codicil executed with proper formalities. Dependent Relative Revocation (DRR) is an equitable doctrine under which a court disregards a revocation that was conditioned on the validity of an alternative disposition; if the revocation was based on a mistake of fact or law and would not have occurred absent that mistaken belief, and the prior will more closely reflects the testator’s wishes than intestacy, the court may treat the revocation as ineffective and give effect to the earlier will.
cards.hardContent: Revival addresses what happens when a revoking instrument itself is revoked: if Will 1 is revoked by Will 2, and Will 2 is later revoked, many jurisdictions presume that Will 1 is revived, subject to contrary intent shown by the testator’s statements or other evidence. Alternatively, a revoked will may be affirmatively re‑executed by a subsequent will or codicil that satisfies all testamentary formalities. Dependent Relative Revocation (DRR) is a court‑created doctrine that treats a revocation as dependent on the effectiveness of a replacement disposition. If the testator revokes a will to create an alternative plan, but that plan fails because of a mistake of fact or law, the court may disregard the revocation and give effect to the earlier will when (1) the revocation was premised on that mistake, (2) the revocation would not have occurred but for the mistaken belief that the new disposition was valid, and (3) honoring the revoked will more closely approximates the testator’s intent than allowing intestate succession or some other default result.
cards.mnemonic: DRR: Revocation Depends on Reality—if mistake, restore prior will.
cards.clozeLite: Revival lets {{c1::Will 1 revive when Will 2 is revoked}}, if {{c2::testator intended revival}}. {{c3::DRR}} lets courts {{c4::disregard a mistaken revocation}} to {{c5::better match testator’s intent}}.

cards.topic: Lapsed Gifts and Anti Lapse Statutes
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 017. Lapsed Gifts and Anti Lapse Statutes
cards.front: Lapsed Gifts and Anti Lapse Statutes
cards.backPlain: A gift provided in a will lapses where the beneficiary predeceases the testator. Absent application of an anti-lapse statute, the gift will go back into the residue of the testator's estate. 1. Anti-lapse statutes: a gift that would otherwise lapse vests in the predeceased beneficiary's descendants, who become substitutes. 1.1 Application: the lapsed gift will be saved if the predeceased beneficiary was: 1.1.1 A relative of the testator (usually descendants only). 1.1.2 And had descendants. 1.2 Who may be substituted: some states allow only the testator's descendants, while others (and the UPC) allow any of the testator's relatives. 2. Lapse in the residue: this can arise where a bequest is made to a person who predeceases the testator and the anti-lapse statute does not apply (e.g., the predeceased beneficiary was not the testator's relative). 2.1 Common law: the lapsed gift passes to the testator's heirs via intestacy. 2.2 Modern view: residuary beneficiaries who survive the testator and the deceased beneficiary take the deceased beneficiary's share. 3. Class gifts: 3.1 If a will makes a gift to a class of people and a class member predeceases the testator, surviving class members take the predeceased member's gift absent an alternative provision in the testator's will. 3.2 Exception: if an anti-lapse statute applies to the predeceasing class member (e.g., the predeceased was the testator's relative and has surviving descendants), the gift vests in the predeceased member's descendants, not the class.
cards.frontPrompt: What happens when a beneficiary under a will predeceases the testator, and how do anti-lapse statutes, lapse in the residue, and class gift rules affect the disposition?
cards.cloze: A gift provided in a will {{c1::lapses}} where the beneficiary {{c2::predeceases the testator}}. Absent application of an {{c3::anti-lapse statute}}, the gift will go back into the {{c4::residue}} of the testator's estate. 1. {{c5::Anti-lapse statutes}}: a gift that would otherwise lapse vests in the predeceased beneficiary's {{c6::descendants}}, who become substitutes. 1.1 Application: the lapsed gift will be saved if the predeceased beneficiary was: 1.1.1 A {{c7::relative of the testator}} (usually descendants only). 1.1.2 And {{c8::had descendants}}. 1.2 Who may be substituted: some states allow only the testator's {{c9::descendants}}, while others (and the {{c10::UPC}}) allow any of the testator's {{c11::relatives}}. 2. {{c12::Lapse in the residue}}: this can arise where a bequest is made to a person who predeceases the testator and the anti-lapse statute does not apply (e.g., the predeceased beneficiary was not the testator's relative). 2.1 {{c13::Common law}}: the lapsed gift passes to the testator's heirs via {{c14::intestacy}}. 2.2 {{c15::Modern view}}: {{c16::residuary beneficiaries}} who survive the testator and the deceased beneficiary take the deceased beneficiary's share. 3. {{c17::Class gifts}}: 3.1 If a will makes a gift to a class of people and a class member predeceases the testator, {{c18::surviving class members}} take the predeceased member's gift absent an alternative provision in the testator's will. 3.2 Exception: if an anti-lapse statute applies to the predeceasing class member (e.g., the predeceased was the testator's relative and has surviving descendants), the gift vests in the {{c19::predeceased member's descendants}}, not the class.
cards.easyContent: If a beneficiary dies before the testator, the gift normally lapses and falls into the residue, but anti-lapse statutes often save the gift for the beneficiary’s descendants, and special rules apply to lapses in the residue and class gifts.
cards.mediumContent: A gift lapses when the beneficiary predeceases the testator, and unless an anti-lapse statute applies, the gift falls into the residuary estate. Anti-lapse statutes typically redirect such gifts to the predeceased beneficiary's descendants if the beneficiary was a qualifying relative and left descendants, with some states limiting substitution to the testator’s descendants and others (including the UPC) extending it to any relatives. If a residuary beneficiary predeceases and anti-lapse does not apply, common law sends that share by intestacy, while the modern rule gives the remaining residuary beneficiaries the deceased beneficiary’s share. For class gifts, surviving class members take a predeceasing member’s share unless an anti-lapse statute saves that member’s share for their descendants.
cards.hardContent: A testamentary gift lapses when the named beneficiary dies before the testator; without an applicable anti-lapse statute, the lapsed gift reverts to the residue of the estate. Anti-lapse statutes prevent this outcome by vesting what would otherwise be a lapsed gift in the predeceased beneficiary’s descendants, who step into the beneficiary’s shoes. These statutes typically require that (1) the beneficiary be a relative of the testator (often limited to lineal descendants) and (2) the beneficiary leave surviving descendants. Some jurisdictions allow substitution only for the testator’s descendants, while others and the UPC extend it to a broader category of the testator’s relatives. A lapse in the residue occurs when a residuary beneficiary predeceases the testator and anti-lapse does not apply: under common law, that lapsed residuary share passes by intestacy, whereas under the modern view, the surviving residuary beneficiaries divide the lapsed share. For class gifts, the default is that surviving class members take the entire class gift if one member predeceases, unless the will provides otherwise; however, if an anti-lapse statute applies to the predeceasing class member (because they are a qualifying relative with descendants), that member’s share passes to their descendants, not to the surviving class members.
cards.mnemonic: LAD: Lapse, Anti‑lapse, Descendants get saved gifts.
cards.clozeLite: A gift {{c1::lapses}} if the {{c2::beneficiary predeceases the testator}}. {{c3::Anti-lapse statutes}} can pass it to {{c4::the beneficiary’s descendants}} instead of {{c5::falling into the residue}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 018. Ademption
cards.backPlain: Under the doctrine of ademption, a gift of specific property in a will fails if it is no longer in the testator's estate at death. 1. Applies to specific devises only 1.1. Ademption only occurs with specific gifts that are satisfied only by giving the actual described property. 1.2. Example: T's will gives T's diamond necklace to A, but T sells it before her death. Upon T's death, the gift to A is adeemed (it fails) because the gift was a specific item of irreplaceable property. 2. Not applicable to general or demonstrative devises 2.1. General devise: gift of a dollar amount payable from the estate's assets. 2.2. Demonstrative devise: gift of a general amount that identifies some asset as a source of the payment (e.g., certain stock holdings). Where a general or demonstrative gift cannot be fully satisfied from the identified asset (e.g., the stock is not worth as much as provided in the demonstrative legacy), the estate generally must sell off other property to satisfy the gift. 3. Exception in intent-theory states 3.1. A minority of states apply the "intent theory" of ademption, under which an adeemed bequest is saved if evidence establishes that ademption would be inconsistent with the testator's intent. 3.2. Effect: the beneficiary gets the monetary value of the specific bequest or the property that was acquired as a replacement for the adeemed gift.

cards.easyContent: Ademption means a specific gift in a will fails if the property is not in the testator’s estate at death, and this doctrine applies only to specific devises.
cards.mediumContent: Ademption applies only to specific devises—gifts satisfied only by transferring the described item—so if that property is gone at death, the gift fails. General and demonstrative devises are not subject to ademption; if the identified source is insufficient, the estate must use other assets. In minority intent-theory states, an adeemed gift can be saved if ademption would contradict the testator’s intent, giving the beneficiary the value or replacement property.
cards.hardContent: Under the doctrine of ademption, a gift of specific property in a will fails if it is no longer in the testator's estate at death. Ademption applies only to specific devises—specific gifts that are satisfied only by giving the actual described property, such as a particular diamond necklace. It does not apply to general devises (a dollar amount payable from estate assets) or demonstrative devises (a general amount with a designated source, such as certain stock holdings); if the source is insufficient for a general or demonstrative gift, the estate must sell other property to satisfy it. In a minority of intent-theory states, an adeemed bequest may be saved if evidence shows ademption would be inconsistent with the testator's intent, in which case the beneficiary receives the monetary value of the specific bequest or replacement property.

cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 019. Abatement
cards.backPlain: Where an estate's value is insufficient to pay its obligations and provide for disposition of property under a will, it must reduce (abate) gifts in order to pay the obligations and satisfy some bequests and devises. 1. Requirement to pay obligations 1.1. The estate must always pay off obligations before distributing assets (i.e., satisfy debts, expenses, taxes, etc.). 1.2. Abatement occurs when, after doing so, the estate lacks sufficient funds to carry out disposition of property under the terms of the will. 2. Order of abatement 2.1. The testator's will may set out an order of abatement. 2.2. Absent provisions in the will, most state statutes provide for an order of abatement setting a priority as to which categories of property in the estate will be sold off first. 2.3. Order (most states abate estate property in the following order): 2.3.1. Property not disposed of by will (i.e., passing by intestacy). 2.3.2. Residuary estate (i.e., the portion that would remain after all specific gifts and bequests have been made). 2.3.3. General devises (abate pro rata). 2.3.4. Specific devises and bequests.
cards.frontPrompt: What is abatement in the context of wills, and in what order are gifts typically abated when the estate is insufficient?

Requirement to pay obligations 1.1. The estate must always {{c2::pay off obligations before distributing assets}} (i.e., satisfy debts, expenses, taxes, etc.). 1.2. {{c3::Abatement}} occurs when, after doing so, the estate lacks sufficient funds to carry out disposition of property under the terms of the will. 2. Order of abatement 2.1. The testator's will may set out an {{c4::order of abatement}}. 2.2. Absent provisions in the will, most state statutes provide for an order of abatement setting a priority as to which categories of property in the estate will be sold off first. 2.3. Order (most states abate estate property in the following order): 2.3.1. {{c5::Property not disposed of by will}} (i.e., passing by intestacy). 2.3.2. {{c6::Residuary estate}} (i.e., the portion that would remain after all specific gifts and bequests have been made). 2.3.3. {{c7::General devises}} (abate pro rata). 2.3.4. {{c8::Specific devises and bequests}}.
cards.easyContent: Abatement occurs when the estate is too small to pay debts and all gifts, so gifts are reduced in a set order to satisfy obligations first.
cards.mediumContent: Abatement is the reduction of testamentary gifts when the estate is insufficient to pay debts and carry out all dispositions. The estate must first pay obligations such as debts, expenses, and taxes. If funds are still insufficient, gifts are abated, either in the order the will specifies or, absent such direction, under statutory priority: property passing by intestacy, then the residuary estate, then general devises (pro rata), and lastly specific devises and bequests.
cards.hardContent: Abatement arises when an estate's value is insufficient to pay its obligations and still fund all testamentary gifts, requiring reduction of gifts to pay debts, expenses, taxes, and then as many bequests and devises as possible. The estate must always satisfy obligations before distributing assets. If the will specifies an order of abatement, that governs. Otherwise, most statutes require abating in this order: (1) property not disposed of by will (intestate property), (2) the residuary estate, (3) general devises on a pro rata basis, and (4) specific devises and bequests.
cards.mnemonic: Think "I-R-G-S": Intestate, Residuary, General, Specific.
cards.clozeLite: Abatement is {{c1::reduction of testamentary gifts}} when the estate is {{c2::insufficient to pay debts}}; gifts abate {{c3::intestacy, residuary, general, specific}}.

cards.topic: Contracts Involving Wills, Joint and Mutual Wills
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 020. Contracts Involving Wills, Joint and Mutual Wills
cards.front: Contracts Involving Wills, Joint and Mutual Wills
cards.backPlain: Contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will are enforceable if they satisfy ordinary contract requirements (mutual assent, consideration) and are governed by contract law; they are not themselves wills. Most states require such contracts to be in writing, and under the UPC the writing requirement can be satisfied by: (1) will provisions stating the material provisions of the contract; (2) an express reference in the will to the contract plus extrinsic evidence proving its terms; or (3) a separate writing signed by the decedent evidencing the contract. On breach—such as when the testator fails to provide as promised—the usual remedy is to probate the will and impose a constructive trust in favor of the intended contract beneficiary. Joint wills (a single document executed by two or more people) are admissible to probate upon either testator’s death and may be interpreted as a contract not to revoke, whereas mutual wills (separate but reciprocal wills) are usually not construed as a binding contract to make or not revoke a will.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic rules for contracts involving wills, including writing requirements, typical remedy for breach, and how joint and mutual wills differ?

Most states require such contracts to be {{c4::in writing}}. Under the {{c5::UPC}}, the writing requirement can be satisfied by: (1) will provisions stating the {{c6::material provisions of the contract}}; (2) an {{c7::express reference in the will to the contract}} plus extrinsic evidence of its terms; or (3) a separate {{c8::writing signed by the decedent}} evidencing the contract. On breach, courts typically {{c9::admit the will to probate}} and impose a {{c10::constructive trust}} in favor of the intended beneficiary.
