cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 021. Will Contests and No Contest Clauses
cards.front: Will Contests and No Contest Clauses
cards.backPlain: A will may be contested for any number of reasons challenging its validity. 1. Common grounds for contesting a will 1.1. Lack of capacity or lack of testamentary intent. 1.2. Defective execution (failure to comply with required formalities). 1.3. Undue influence, fraud, or mistake. 1.4. Will has been revoked. 2. Standing to contest a will 2.1. Generally, only those with a pecuniary interest have standing to contest. 2.2. This includes beneficiaries, someone who should be a beneficiary, or someone who would benefit if the decedent had died intestate. 3. No-contest clauses 3.1. A no-contest (in terrorem) clause is a clause in a will providing that a beneficiary loses their interest under the will if they contest it. 3.2. A no-contest clause does not apply to suits challenging the executor's appointment, jurisdiction, or asking the court to interpret the will. 4. Application of no-contest clauses 4.1. States vary on how strictly they apply no-contest clauses. 4.2. Majority: no forfeiture of interest if the beneficiary challenges in good faith and on the basis of probable cause. 4.3. Minority: no-contest clauses are given full effect regardless of the challenging beneficiary's cause or intent.

cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 022. Undue Influence and Fraud
cards.backPlain: 1. Undue influence (a will is invalid if executed while the testator was subject to undue influence that effectively overrode the testator's free will) 1.1. Requirements (the will contestant has the burden of proof and must show): 1.1.1. Influence was exerted on the testator. 1.1.2. The testator's mind and free will were overpowered. 1.1.3. The testator's will would not have been executed absent the undue influence. 1.2. Presumption (a presumption of undue influence arises if): 1.2.1. A confidential relationship (e.g., attorney–client) existed between the testator and the beneficiary who exerted influence. 1.2.2. The beneficiary participated to a significant degree in executing, drafting, or procuring the testator's will. 1.2.3. Once established, the burden shifts to the proponent of the will (usually the beneficiary) to prove the will was not induced by undue influence. 2. Fraud (where a will or one or more of its provisions are the result of fraud, the will or the provision is invalid) 2.1. Requirements (it must be shown that the testator has been intentionally deceived as to): 2.1.1. The character or content of the will or its provisions; and/or 2.1.2. Facts extrinsic to the will that would induce the will or a particular provision or disposition in the will; and 2.1.3. The testator acted in reliance on the misrepresentation (i.e., he would not have made the gift or executed the will if he knew the facts).

cards.mediumContent: To prove undue influence, the contestant must show influence was exerted, that it overpowered the testator’s mind and free will, and that the will would not have been executed but for that influence. A presumption of undue influence arises where there is a confidential relationship between testator and beneficiary and the beneficiary significantly participates in drafting, executing, or procuring the will, shifting the burden to the proponent to disprove undue influence. Fraud invalidates a will or provision when the testator is intentionally deceived about the will’s character or contents, or about extrinsic facts that induce the disposition, and the testator acts in reliance on that misrepresentation.
cards.hardContent: Undue influence renders a will invalid if it was executed while the testator was subject to influence that effectively overrode the testator's free will. The contestant must prove that influence was exerted on the testator, that the testator's mind and free will were overpowered, and that the will would not have been executed absent that influence. A presumption of undue influence arises when the alleged influencer is in a confidential relationship with the testator (such as attorney–client) and significantly participates in drafting, executing, or procuring the will; once this presumption is established, the burden shifts to the proponent of the will to show that it was not induced by undue influence. Fraud in the will context exists where a will or one or more of its provisions are the product of intentional deception. The contestant must show the testator was intentionally deceived either as to the character or content of the will or its provisions, or as to extrinsic facts that would induce execution of the will or a particular disposition, and that the testator relied on the misrepresentation—i.e., would not have made the gift or executed the will if the true facts were known.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 023. Mistake (Wills)
cards.backPlain: Mistakes in wills may occur in executing the will or in the inclusion or omission of provisions, but relief is often limited. The main categories are: 1. Mistake as to nature of instrument: Testator is mistaken about what document is being signed (e.g., does not realize it is a will); extrinsic evidence may be used to show this lack of testamentary intent, and the will may fail for lack of testamentary intent. 2. Mistake in inducement: Testator is mistaken about the reasons for making the will or a particular gift or omission; courts generally do not grant relief for such mistakes unless there is an independent ground to contest the will (e.g., fraud or undue influence). 3. Mistaken omission or misstatement of intent: Courts traditionally do not admit extrinsic evidence to add omitted provisions or correct terms that do not reflect actual intent, again absent other grounds like fraud or undue influence. 4. Reformation under the UPC: The UPC allows courts to reform a will to conform to the testator’s intent when a mistake of law or fact is shown by clear and convincing evidence, and permits use of extrinsic evidence (including to resolve both latent and patent ambiguities).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main categories of mistake in wills, and in general when is relief or reformation available?

The main categories are: 1. {{c2::Mistake as to nature of instrument}} – Testator is mistaken about what document is being signed (e.g., does not realize it is a will); {{c3::extrinsic evidence}} may be used to show lack of {{c4::testamentary intent}}, and the will may fail. 2. {{c5::Mistake in inducement}} – Testator is mistaken about the {{c6::reasons for making the will or a particular gift or omission}}; courts generally do {{c7::not grant relief}} unless there is an {{c8::independent ground to contest the will}} (fraud, undue influence). 3. {{c9::Mistaken omission or misstatement of intent}} – Courts traditionally do {{c10::not admit extrinsic evidence}} to add omitted provisions or correct terms that do not reflect actual intent, absent another ground like fraud. 4. {{c11::Reformation under the UPC}} – Courts may {{c12::reform a will}} to conform to the testator’s intent when a {{c13::mistake of law or fact}} is shown by {{c14::clear and convincing evidence}}, and may use {{c15::extrinsic evidence}} to resolve both {{c16::latent and patent ambiguities}}.
cards.easyContent: Mistakes in wills fall into four categories: nature of the instrument, mistake in inducement, mistaken omission or misstatement, and, under the UPC, reformation for proven mistakes. Relief is usually denied for inducement and omissions, but may be available if the testator didn’t know he was signing a will or under the UPC’s reformation rule.
cards.mediumContent: Wills mistakes include: (1) mistake as to nature of instrument, where extrinsic evidence can show the testator did not realize he was signing a will, defeating testamentary intent; (2) mistake in inducement, where courts do not give relief for a mistaken reason for making or omitting a gift, absent an independent ground like fraud or undue influence; (3) mistaken omission or misstatement, where courts traditionally will not admit extrinsic evidence to add omitted terms or correct provisions that do not match actual intent, again absent other grounds like fraud; and (4) reformation under the UPC, which allows a court to reform a will if clear and convincing evidence shows a mistake of law or fact affected the terms and the testator’s intent, and permits extrinsic evidence to resolve both latent and patent ambiguities.
cards.hardContent: Mistakes in wills may concern execution or content, and relief is often restricted. (1) Mistake as to nature of instrument: If the testator is mistaken about what document is being signed (for example, does not realize it is his will), extrinsic evidence is admissible to show this error. Because the testator then lacks testamentary intent, the will may be invalid. (2) Mistake in inducement: Where the error concerns the testator’s reasons for creating the will or a particular gift or omission (e.g., an incorrect belief about a beneficiary’s conduct or status), courts generally will not reform or invalidate provisions based solely on this mistake. Relief may be available only if there is a separate ground for contesting the will, such as fraud, duress, or undue influence. (3) Mistaken omission or misstatement of intent: Traditionally, courts exclude extrinsic evidence offered solely to show that the will mistakenly omitted a provision or contains terms that do not reflect the testator’s true intent, and they do not rewrite the will on this basis alone. Again, relief may be possible only through an independent challenge (e.g., fraud). (4) Reformation for mistake under the UPC: The UPC authorizes courts to reform the terms of a will to conform to the testator’s actual intent if it is established by clear and convincing evidence that a mistake of law or fact affected the terms and the testator’s intent. In doing so, courts may consider extrinsic evidence, including evidence to resolve both latent and patent ambiguities.
cards.mnemonic: N-I-O-R: Nature, Inducement, Omission, UPC Reformation.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 024. Non Probate Transfers
cards.backPlain: The following are common methods of transferring property outside of probate. 1. Inter vivos gift (a gift given by a living person to another living person) 1.1 Requirements (intent, delivery, and acceptance): 1.1.1 The donor intends to make a gift. 1.1.2 The donor delivers the gift (actual or constructive delivery). 1.1.3 The donee accepts the gift. 2. Joint tenant bank account 2.1 A surviving joint tenant is generally entitled to the money in a jointly held account when the other joint tenant dies. 2.2 This usually arises where the account is in the names of two or more people. 3. Totten trust or POD (payable-on-death) account 3.1 Deposit of funds in one's own bank account held in trust for another (e.g., A opens an account for herself as trustee for B). 3.2 This creates a valid revocable trust, even though the depositor retains control. 3.3 Funds pass to the designated beneficiary upon the trustee's death. 3.4 The arrangement is revocable by the trustee-depositor by withdrawing funds before death or revoking the trust by will. 4. Life insurance 4.1 A contract between the policyholder and the insurance company under which a beneficiary is named. 4.2 Unless the contract provides otherwise, the policyholder cannot change the beneficiary through a provision in their will.

cards.easyContent: Common non-probate transfers include inter vivos gifts, joint tenant bank accounts, Totten or payable-on-death accounts, and life insurance proceeds passing to named beneficiaries.
cards.mediumContent: Property can pass outside probate through: (1) inter vivos gifts, which require donor intent, delivery, and donee acceptance; (2) joint tenant bank accounts, where the surviving joint tenant takes the funds on the other's death; (3) Totten trusts or POD accounts, which are revocable arrangements where a depositor holds a bank account in trust for another and the beneficiary takes at the depositor-trustee's death; and (4) life insurance contracts, under which proceeds go to the named beneficiary and, absent contrary contract terms, cannot be redirected by will.
cards.hardContent: Non-probate transfers include several devices: (1) Inter vivos gifts: a living donor transfers property to a living donee, requiring intent to make a gift, actual or constructive delivery, and acceptance. (2) Joint tenant bank accounts: when an account is held in joint tenancy, the surviving joint tenant is generally entitled to the funds at the other's death. (3) Totten trusts or POD (payable-on-death) accounts: the depositor opens an account in her own name as trustee for another; this creates a valid revocable trust even though the depositor retains control, with funds passing to the named beneficiary at the trustee's death and revocable by withdrawal or revocation (including by will). (4) Life insurance: a contract between the policyholder and insurer naming a beneficiary; unless the contract permits, the policyholder cannot alter the beneficiary designation by will, so the proceeds pass outside of probate.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 025. Power of Appointment
cards.backPlain: 1. Power of appointment is authority granted to a person (the donee) enabling the donee to designate a new owner of property and how they take it. 1.1 Meaning: The donor-testator gives the donee a power of appointment. 1.2 This usually arises with testamentary wills that create trusts. 1.3 Example: T's will leaves property in trust and gives C a power of appointment over the trust property. 2. General vs. special (a power of appointment can be general or special) 2.1 General: The donee can exercise her power in favor of anyone, including herself, her estate, her creditors, or the creditors of her estate. 2.2 Special: The power is exercisable in favor of a limited class of appointees and cannot include the donee, her estate, her creditors, or the creditors of her estate. 3. Present vs. testamentary power (the appointment power may be exercisable during the donee's life or only by the donee's will) 3.1 Presently exercisable: One exercisable by the donee during her life. 3.2 Testamentary power: Exercisable only by the donee's will. 3.3 Example: T's will leaves property in trust and provides that C's exercise of her power of appointment is limited to her will, creating a testamentary power of appointment.

cards.easyContent: A power of appointment lets a donee designate who will receive certain property, and powers are classified as general or special and as presently exercisable or testamentary.
cards.mediumContent: A power of appointment is authority given by a donor-testator to a donee to decide who will take specified property and on what terms, often in the context of testamentary trusts. A general power allows the donee to appoint to anyone, including herself, her estate, and their creditors, while a special power restricts appointments to a limited class that cannot include the donee, her estate, or their creditors. Powers may be presently exercisable during the donee's life or testamentary, exercisable only through the donee's will.
cards.hardContent: A power of appointment is authority granted by a donor-testator to a donee to designate the ultimate owner(s) of certain property and the manner in which they take it, commonly arising in testamentary trusts. The donor creates the power in favor of a donee. Powers are classified by scope and timing: (1) Scope: A general power of appointment allows the donee to appoint the property to anyone, including herself, her estate, her creditors, or the creditors of her estate. A special (or limited) power confines appointments to a defined class of permissible appointees and expressly excludes the donee, her estate, and their creditors. (2) Timing: A presently exercisable power may be exercised by the donee during her lifetime, while a testamentary power is exercisable only through the donee's will, such as when T's will states that C may appoint the trust property only by will.

cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::power of appointment}} lets a {{c2::donee}} decide who takes property. A {{c3::general}} power can appoint to anyone, including the donee, while a {{c4::special}} power is limited to a class excluding the donee.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 026. Probate and Estate Administration
cards.backPlain: In a probate proceeding, a personal representative is appointed to carry out administration of the decedent's estate. 1. Executor 1.1 An executor is one named in the decedent's will to be the personal representative. 1.2 If no executor is named in a will, or the decedent dies intestate, the court appoints a personal representative (usually a surviving spouse or heir of the decedent). 1.3 Capacity: Any person with the capacity to contract can be a personal representative (i.e., must be mentally competent and not a minor). 2. Responsibilities 2.1 Generally, a representative or executor handles all matters associated with winding up the decedent's estate. 2.2 Examples include: filing paperwork, paying creditors, notifying beneficiaries and devisees, and managing property distributions.
cards.frontPrompt: In probate, who serves as the personal representative, what are the capacity requirements, and what are the representative’s main responsibilities?

cards.easyContent: In probate, a personal representative (often an executor named in the will or a court-appointed heir or spouse) administers the estate and must be a mentally competent adult with capacity to contract.
cards.mediumContent: Probate administration is carried out by a personal representative. If named in the will, that person is the executor; if no executor is named or the decedent dies intestate, the court appoints a representative, typically a surviving spouse or heir, who must have capacity to contract (mentally competent and not a minor). The representative is responsible for winding up the estate, including filing necessary paperwork, paying creditors, notifying beneficiaries and devisees, and managing property distributions.
cards.hardContent: In probate, the court oversees administration of the decedent's estate through a personal representative. When the decedent's will names a representative, that person is called the executor. If no executor is named, the will fails to nominate one, or the decedent dies intestate, the court appoints a personal representative, usually giving preference to a surviving spouse or heir. To serve, a person must have capacity to contract—meaning they are mentally competent and not a minor. The representative or executor is charged with handling all tasks associated with winding up the estate, such as preparing and filing required probate documents, marshalling and managing estate assets, paying valid creditor claims, providing notice to beneficiaries and devisees, and overseeing and effecting distribution of estate property in accordance with the will or intestacy statutes.

cards.topic: Living Wills, Durable Power of Attorney
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 027. Living Wills, Durable Power of Attorney
cards.front: Living Wills, Durable Power of Attorney
cards.backPlain: 1. Living wills and durable healthcare powers (a.k.a. durable healthcare powers of attorney) are forms of advanced healthcare directives, which are instructions regarding an individual's health care if they become unable to make such decisions on their own. 1.1 Creation (states vary on requirements, but most are similar to those needed for will execution): 1.1.1 In writing. 1.1.2 Signed by the testator or principal, or another at his direction. 1.1.3 Witnessed by two adults. 1.2 Revocation: Both a living will and a durable healthcare power of attorney may be revoked. 2. Living will 2.1 A document specifying life-sustaining and pain-alleviating measures one does or does not want if he is indefinitely incapacitated. 2.2 Example: Directs what measures one wants if they become terminally ill or are in a persistent vegetative state. 3. Durable healthcare power of attorney 3.1 A document that appoints an individual as agent to make healthcare decisions on behalf of the principal. 3.2 Becomes effective only if the principal is incapacitated. 3.3 Extends to all healthcare questions, unless otherwise limited. 4. Family consent 4.1 Most states have laws that apply where a person becomes terminally ill or otherwise indefinitely incapacitated and there is no living will or durable healthcare power of attorney. 4.2 Close relatives, usually in an order provided by statute, may act as surrogate decision-makers.
cards.frontPrompt: What are living wills and durable healthcare powers of attorney, how are they created and revoked, and what role does family consent play if no directive exists?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Living wills}} and {{c2::durable healthcare powers}} (a.k.a. durable healthcare powers of attorney) are forms of {{c3::advanced healthcare directives}}, which are instructions regarding an individual's health care if they become unable to make such decisions on their own. 1.1 Creation (states vary on requirements, but most are similar to those needed for will execution): 1.1.1 In {{c4::writing}}. 1.1.2 {{c5::Signed}} by the testator or principal, or another at his direction. 1.1.3 {{c6::Witnessed by two adults}}. 1.2 Revocation: Both a living will and a durable healthcare power of attorney may be {{c7::revoked}}. 2. {{c8::Living will}} 2.1 A document specifying {{c9::life-sustaining and pain-alleviating measures}} one does or does not want if he is indefinitely incapacitated. 2.2 Example: Directs what measures one wants if they become terminally ill or are in a {{c10::persistent vegetative state}}. 3. {{c11::Durable healthcare power of attorney}} 3.1 A document that {{c12::appoints an individual as agent}} to make healthcare decisions on behalf of the principal. 3.2 Becomes effective only if the {{c13::principal is incapacitated}}. 3.3 Extends to {{c14::all healthcare questions}}, unless otherwise limited. 4. {{c15::Family consent}} 4.1 Most states have laws that apply where a person becomes terminally ill or otherwise indefinitely incapacitated and there is {{c16::no living will or durable healthcare power of attorney}}. 4.2 {{c17::Close relatives}}, usually in an order provided by statute, may act as {{c18::surrogate decision-makers}}.
cards.easyContent: Living wills and durable healthcare powers of attorney are advance directives that state a person’s healthcare wishes or appoint an agent if they later become incapacitated, and they generally must be written, signed, and witnessed.
cards.mediumContent: Advance healthcare directives include living wills, which specify desired or undesired life-sustaining and pain-relief measures if the person is indefinitely incapacitated, and durable healthcare powers of attorney, which appoint an agent to make healthcare decisions if the principal becomes incapacitated. Most states require a writing, signature by or at the direction of the principal, and two adult witnesses, and both forms can be revoked. If no directive exists, state family-consent statutes typically authorize close relatives, in a statutory order of priority, to act as surrogate decision-makers.
cards.hardContent: Living wills and durable healthcare powers of attorney are types of advance healthcare directives, used when an individual later lacks capacity to make medical decisions. Creation requirements vary by state but generally mirror will-execution formalities: the directive must be in writing, signed by the principal (or another at the principal’s direction), and witnessed by two adults. Both instruments are revocable. A living will is a document specifying what life-sustaining and pain-alleviating treatment the person does or does not want if indefinitely incapacitated, such as when terminally ill or in a persistent vegetative state. A durable healthcare power of attorney appoints an agent to make healthcare decisions for the principal; it becomes effective only upon the principal’s incapacity and typically covers all healthcare questions unless limited by its terms. Where no living will or durable healthcare power of attorney exists, most states have family-consent laws that authorize close relatives, in a statutory order of priority, to serve as surrogate decision-makers for major healthcare decisions.

cards.topic: Trust Basics and Types of Trusts
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 028. Trust Basics and Types of Trusts
cards.front: Trust Basics and Types of Trusts – Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. Trust basics 1.1 A trust is a fiduciary relationship in which a trustee holds legal title to property for the benefit of designated beneficiaries. 1.2 Key roles: The settlor creates the trust and transfers legal title to the trustee, who manages and administers trust property for the beneficiaries, who hold equitable interests. 1.3 Revocability: Under modern statutes, trusts are generally revocable unless the terms expressly state that the trust is irrevocable. 2. Main types of trusts 2.1 Express trusts are intentionally created by the property owner and include: • Private trusts for defined or ascertainable beneficiaries, created inter vivos or by will. • Charitable trusts for an indefinite class or the public generally. 2.2 Resulting trusts are implied by law, most often when an express trust fails, and typically return the beneficial interest to the settlor or, if deceased, the settlor's estate. 2.3 Constructive trusts are not true trusts but equitable remedies imposed by courts on property held by a wrongdoer to prevent unjust enrichment.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a trust at a high level, and what are the main categories of trusts (express, resulting, and constructive)?
cards.cloze: 1. Trust basics 1.1 A trust is a {{c1::fiduciary relationship}} in which a {{c2::trustee}} holds {{c3::legal title}} to property for the benefit of {{c4::beneficiaries}}. 1.2 Key roles: The {{c5::settlor}} creates the trust and transfers legal title to the trustee, who manages and administers property for the beneficiaries, who hold {{c6::equitable interests}}. 1.3 {{c7::Revocability}}: Under modern statutes, trusts are generally {{c8::revocable}} unless expressly made {{c9::irrevocable}}. 2. Main types of trusts 2.1 {{c10::Express trusts}}: intentionally created by the property owner, including {{c11::private trusts}} (for defined or ascertainable beneficiaries, inter vivos or testamentary) and {{c12::charitable trusts}} (for an indefinite class or the public). 2.2 {{c13::Resulting trusts}}: implied by law, most often when an {{c14::express trust fails}}, typically returning the beneficial interest to the {{c15::settlor}} or the settlor's {{c16::estate}}. 2.3 {{c17::Constructive trusts}}: {{c18::equitable remedies}} imposed on property held by a {{c19::wrongdoer}} to prevent {{c20::unjust enrichment}}.
cards.easyContent: A trust is a fiduciary relationship where a trustee holds legal title to property for beneficiaries. Main categories: express trusts (private and charitable), resulting trusts, and constructive trusts (an equitable remedy).
cards.mediumContent: A trust is a fiduciary relationship in which a trustee holds legal title to property for beneficiaries, created by a settlor who transfers property to the trustee. Under modern law, trusts are generally revocable unless made irrevocable in the terms. The main categories are: (1) express trusts, intentionally created by the owner, including private trusts for defined beneficiaries (inter vivos or testamentary) and charitable trusts for an indefinite class or the public; (2) resulting trusts, implied when an express trust fails, typically returning beneficial ownership to the settlor or the settlor's estate; and (3) constructive trusts, equitable remedies imposed on property held by a wrongdoer to prevent unjust enrichment.
cards.hardContent: A trust is a fiduciary relationship where the settlor transfers legal title to property to a trustee, who holds and manages it for the benefit of equitable owners (beneficiaries). Modern statutes generally make trusts revocable unless the instrument expressly states that the trust is irrevocable. The principal categories are: • Express trusts, which arise from the owner's express intent and include private trusts for defined or ascertainable beneficiaries (created inter vivos or by will) and charitable trusts for an indefinite class or the public. • Resulting trusts, which are implied by law, usually when an express trust fails (e.g., no living beneficiary, void or unenforceable provisions), causing the trustee to hold and convey property back to the settlor or, if deceased, the settlor's estate. • Constructive trusts, which are not true trusts but equitable remedies. A court imposes a constructive trust on property in a wrongdoer’s possession to prevent unjust enrichment from wrongful conduct.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 029. Express Private Trust Elements
cards.backPlain: A valid express private trust requires the following elements: 1. Settlor with capacity to convey 1.1 The settlor must have capacity to convey, which is the same capacity required to create a will. 2. Clear present intent to create a trust relationship 2.1 The settlor must have absolutely clear intent and must understand the nature of the act (i.e., what a trust is). 2.2 A writing is not required unless required by the Statute of Wills or Statute of Frauds (for example, for real property). 3. Competent trustee with duties 3.1 The settlor must name a trustee, but once established, a trust will not fail solely because a trustee does not exist; in such cases, a trustee will be appointed. 3.2 Trustee capacity: In most states, anyone who can hold title to property can act as a trustee. 4. Definite beneficiary 4.1 At the time of trust creation, the settlor must either specifically identify the beneficiaries by name or sufficiently describe how the beneficiaries will be ascertained. 4.2 This requirement does not apply to charitable trusts. 4.3 The sole trustee cannot be the sole beneficiary of a trust. 5. Present and clear disposition of specific trust property 5.1 The settlor must have specific property they want to place in trust. 5.2 The trust property must be specifically described or ascertainable with certainty from its description. 6. Valid trust purpose 6.1 The trust must be for a purpose that is not illegal, impossible, or contrary to public policy.
cards.frontPrompt: What elements are required to create a valid express private trust?

cards.easyContent: A valid express private trust requires a competent settlor with capacity, clear present intent, a competent trustee with duties, definite beneficiaries, specific trust property, and a valid, lawful purpose.
cards.mediumContent: To create a valid express private trust, the settlor must (1) have capacity to convey (same as for a will); (2) clearly and presently intend to create a trust, with writing only required where the Statute of Wills or Statute of Frauds applies; (3) name a competent trustee with duties, noting that a trust will not fail for lack of a trustee because a court can appoint one; (4) provide definite beneficiaries, identified by name or clear description, except in charitable trusts, and the sole trustee cannot also be the sole beneficiary; (5) transfer or identify specific trust property that is described or ascertainable with certainty; and (6) establish a valid trust purpose that is not illegal, impossible, or against public policy.
cards.hardContent: A valid express private trust requires six elements: (1) a settlor with capacity to convey, which is the same capacity needed to make a will; (2) a clear present intent to create a trust relationship, with the settlor understanding what a trust is, and no writing required unless mandated by the Statute of Wills or Statute of Frauds (e.g., for real property); (3) a competent trustee with duties—someone capable of holding title to property—though the trust does not fail for lack of a trustee because a court can appoint one; (4) a definite beneficiary, identified by name or by a description that allows ascertainment at creation, with this requirement inapplicable to charitable trusts and the rule that the sole trustee cannot also be the sole beneficiary; (5) a present, clear disposition of specific trust property, which must be identified or ascertainable with certainty; and (6) a valid trust purpose that is not illegal, impossible to carry out, or contrary to public policy.
cards.mnemonic: SPIT-BP: Settlor, Present intent, Identified beneficiaries, Trust property, Business/Purpose.
cards.clozeLite: A valid express private trust requires {{c1::settlor capacity}}, {{c2::clear present intent}}, {{c3::definite beneficiaries and specific trust property}}, and {{c4::a valid, lawful purpose}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 030. Trust Creation
cards.backPlain: Inter vivos and testamentary trusts: Trusts are generally created inter vivos (during the settlor's life) or as testamentary trusts (trusts created by will). 1. Inter vivos trusts 1.1 Transfer of property: The property owner transfers property to another as trustee. 1.2 Declaration of trust: The property owner declares himself trustee for another. 1.3 Delivery: If the property owner names another as trustee (i.e., the settlor is not the trustee), the property must be delivered to the trustee. 1.4 Formalities: A writing is not required, but an oral trust and its terms can only be established by clear and convincing evidence. 1.5 Land as trust property: A writing is required under the Statute of Frauds when land is trust property. 2. Testamentary trusts 2.1 A testamentary trust is a trust created by will. 2.2 Trust intent, essential terms, and identification of beneficiaries must be ascertainable by either: 2.2.1 The terms of the will itself; 2.2.2 Incorporation by reference of an existing writing properly incorporated by reference into the will; or 2.2.3 A power of appointment exercised under the will. 3. Pour-over provisions 3.1 A pour-over provision is a provision in a will that devises property to a previously existing trust. 3.2 A pour-over provision does not create a trust. 3.3 It simply transfers property to an existing trust.
cards.frontPrompt: How are trusts created inter vivos and by will, and what are pour-over provisions in wills?
cards.cloze: Inter vivos and testamentary trusts: Trusts are generally created {{c1::inter vivos}} (during the settlor's life) or as {{c2::testamentary trusts}} (trusts created by will). 1. {{c3::Inter vivos trusts}} 1.1 {{c4::Transfer of property}}: The property owner transfers property to another as trustee. 1.2 {{c5::Declaration of trust}}: The property owner declares himself trustee for another. 1.3 {{c6::Delivery}}: If the property owner names another as trustee (i.e., the settlor is not the trustee), the property must be delivered to the trustee. 1.4 {{c7::Formalities}}: A writing is not required, but an {{c8::oral trust}} and its terms can only be established by {{c9::clear and convincing evidence}}. 1.5 {{c10::Land as trust property}}: A {{c11::writing}} is required under the {{c12::Statute of Frauds}} when {{c13::land}} is trust property. 2. {{c14::Testamentary trusts}} 2.1 A testamentary trust is a trust created by {{c15::will}}. 2.2 Trust intent, essential terms, and identification of beneficiaries must be ascertainable by either: 2.2.1 The terms of the {{c16::will itself}}; 2.2.2 {{c17::Incorporation by reference}} of an existing writing properly incorporated by reference into the will; or 2.2.3 A {{c18::power of appointment}} exercised under the will. 3. {{c19::Pour-over provisions}} 3.1 A pour-over provision is a provision in a will that {{c20::devises property to a previously existing trust}}. 3.2 A pour-over provision {{c21::does not create a trust}}. 3.3 It simply {{c22::transfers property}} to an existing trust.
cards.easyContent: Trusts are created either inter vivos, during the settlor’s life by transfer or declaration, or as testamentary trusts under a will. Wills may also contain pour-over provisions that send property into an already existing trust.
cards.mediumContent: Trusts may be created inter vivos by transferring property to a trustee or by a declaration that the owner holds in trust for another; if someone else is named trustee, the property must be delivered. No writing is needed for most inter vivos trusts, but oral trusts must be proven by clear and convincing evidence, and a writing is required for land under the Statute of Frauds. Testamentary trusts are created by will, and the trust intent, essential terms, and beneficiaries must be ascertainable from the will’s terms, an incorporated writing, or a power of appointment exercised in the will. Pour-over provisions in a will do not create a trust but transfer devised property into a previously existing trust.
cards.hardContent: Trust creation occurs either inter vivos or testamentarily. Inter vivos trusts arise when a property owner transfers property to another as trustee or declares himself trustee for another; if the settlor names someone else as trustee, the trust property must be delivered. Inter vivos trusts generally do not require a writing, but an oral trust and its terms must be established by clear and convincing evidence, and a writing is required under the Statute of Frauds when land is the trust property. Testamentary trusts are created by will, and the trust intent, essential terms, and beneficiaries must be ascertainable from the will itself, from a writing properly incorporated by reference, or from a power of appointment exercised under the will. Pour-over provisions in wills are clauses that devise property to a previously existing trust; they do not themselves create a trust but simply transfer property into the existing trust.
cards.mnemonic: I-T-P: Inter vivos, Testamentary, Pour-over to existing trust.
cards.clozeLite: Trusts are created {{c1::inter vivos}} or {{c2::testamentary}}; {{c3::pour-over will provisions}} {{c4::devise property into an existing trust}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 031. Trustee Powers, Responsibilities, and Duties
cards.backPlain: 1. Trustee powers 1.1 The trustee can only exercise powers expressly or impliedly conferred, most often conferred by the trust terms. 1.2 The trustee has powers necessary and appropriate to properly invest, manage, and distribute trust property, so long as those powers are not contrary to the trust terms. 2. Trustee duties 2.1 Duty to administer: The trustee must administer the trust in good faith and in a prudent manner, in accordance with the trust terms and the beneficiaries' interests. 2.2 Duty of loyalty: The trustee must avoid self-dealing and cannot enter into a transaction in which they are dealing with the trust in their individual capacity, absent court approval or a contrary trust provision. 2.3 Duty to report: The trustee must keep beneficiaries reasonably informed of the trust and its administration. 2.4 Duty to separate trust property and keep records: The trustee must not commingle trust property with their own or another trust's property, and must maintain proper records. 2.5 Duty to enforce claims and defend the trust: The trustee must enforce claims the trust has and defend the trust against claims. 2.6 Duty to preserve property and make it productive: The trustee must preserve trust property, including the duty to make property productive (for example, by investing funds, leasing or managing land, or collecting claims).

cards.easyContent: A trustee may exercise only those powers given by the trust or implied as necessary to manage it, and must act as a prudent fiduciary, with duties of good-faith administration, loyalty, reporting, segregation of assets, enforcing claims, and preserving and productively investing trust property.
cards.mediumContent: A trustee’s powers are limited to those expressly or impliedly granted, typically by the trust instrument, and include powers reasonably necessary to invest, manage, and distribute trust property consistent with the terms. The trustee owes key fiduciary duties: to administer in good faith and prudently under the trust terms and beneficiaries’ interests; a strict duty of loyalty prohibiting self-dealing without court or instrument authorization; a duty to keep beneficiaries reasonably informed and provide reports; a duty to segregate trust assets, avoid commingling, and maintain accurate records; a duty to enforce claims on the trust’s behalf and defend it against claims; and a duty to preserve property and make it productive through appropriate investment and management.
cards.hardContent: Trustees may exercise only those powers expressly granted or implied from the trust terms, including all powers necessary and appropriate to properly invest, manage, and distribute trust property, provided they do not conflict with the instrument. As fiduciaries, trustees owe several core duties: (1) the duty to administer the trust in good faith and with prudence, following the trust terms and acting in the beneficiaries’ best interests; (2) the duty of loyalty, forbidding self-dealing or transactions in which the trustee deals with the trust in an individual capacity absent court approval or an authorizing trust provision; (3) the duty to report and account, keeping beneficiaries reasonably informed about the trust and its administration; (4) the duty to segregate trust property from the trustee’s own and other trusts’ assets and to maintain complete and accurate records; (5) the duty to enforce claims held by the trust and to defend the trust against adverse claims; and (6) the duty to preserve trust property and make it productive, which generally requires prudent investment, managing or leasing real estate, and collecting amounts owed to the trust.
cards.mnemonic: Trustee duties A-L-R-S-E-P: Administer, Loyalty, Report, Separate, Enforce, Preserve.
cards.clozeLite: A trustee may exercise only {{c1::powers expressly or impliedly granted}} and must act {{c2::prudently and in good faith}} with {{c3::strict loyalty}} and {{c4::segregation and reporting duties}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 032. Discretionary, Support, and Spendthrift Trusts
cards.backPlain: Discretionary and support trusts restrict a beneficiary's access to trust property by the terms of the trust. 1. Creditor issues generally 1.1 Because beneficiaries have limited access to trust property, their creditors are also limited in accessing the beneficiary's trust interest. 2. Discretionary trusts 2.1 In a discretionary trust, the trustee has absolute power and discretion to make decisions regarding distribution of trust property to beneficiaries. 2.2 Beneficiaries have no right to income until the trustee exercises discretion to distribute property or income. 2.3 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors cannot reach the trust because the beneficiary cannot compel payment from the trust. However, if creditors serve the trustee with process, the trustee must first satisfy the creditor's claims before distributing funds to the beneficiary. 3. Support trusts 3.1 A support trust directs the trustee to pay beneficiaries from the trust as much as is necessary for the beneficiary's support. 3.2 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors generally have the same rights as for a discretionary trust. 4. Spendthrift trusts 4.1 A spendthrift trust prohibits beneficiaries from transferring their interests in the trust, either voluntarily or involuntarily. 4.2 Spendthrift clauses are usually included to protect the beneficiary from their own carelessness. 4.3 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors cannot reach the beneficiary's interest in the trust, but distributions actually made to the beneficiary are reachable. 5. Exceptions for certain creditors 5.1 The following creditors can reach trust property despite a spendthrift or similar restriction: 5.1.1 Spousal or child support claimants; 5.1.2 Those providing basic necessities to the beneficiary; and 5.1.3 Holders of federal or state tax liens.

However, if creditors {{c8::serve the trustee with process}}, the trustee must first {{c9::satisfy the creditor's claims}} before distributing funds to the beneficiary. 3. {{c10::Support trusts}} 3.1 A support trust directs the trustee to pay beneficiaries from the trust as much as is necessary for the beneficiary's {{c11::support}}. 3.2 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors generally have the {{c12::same rights as for a discretionary trust}}. 4. {{c13::Spendthrift trusts}} 4.1 A spendthrift trust {{c14::prohibits beneficiaries from transferring}} their interests in the trust, either voluntarily or involuntarily. 4.2 Spendthrift clauses are usually included to {{c15::protect the beneficiary from their own carelessness}}. 4.3 Beneficiary's creditors: Creditors {{c16::cannot reach the beneficiary's interest}} in the trust, but {{c17::distributions actually made}} to the beneficiary are reachable. 5. {{c18::Exceptions for certain creditors}} 5.1 The following creditors can reach trust property despite a spendthrift or similar restriction: 5.1.1 {{c19::Spousal or child support}} claimants; 5.1.2 Those providing {{c20::basic necessities}} to the beneficiary; and 5.1.3 Holders of {{c21::federal or state tax liens}}.
cards.easyContent: Discretionary and support trusts give the trustee control over distributions, limiting beneficiaries’ and thus creditors’ access, while spendthrift trusts bar assignment of the beneficiary’s interest. Certain creditors—like support claimants, providers of necessities, and tax authorities—can still reach trust assets despite spendthrift protection.
cards.mediumContent: In discretionary trusts, the trustee has absolute discretion over distributions, so beneficiaries have no enforceable right to income until the trustee acts, and creditors likewise cannot compel distributions, though served process must be honored before paying the beneficiary. Support trusts require the trustee to distribute only what is necessary for the beneficiary’s support, and creditors generally have the same limited access as in discretionary trusts. Spendthrift trusts bar voluntary and involuntary transfers of the beneficiary’s interest, preventing most creditors from reaching that interest, although amounts actually distributed to the beneficiary can be reached. Exceptions allow certain creditors—such as those owed spousal or child support, those who provided necessities, and holders of federal or state tax liens—to reach trust property despite spendthrift or similar limitations.
cards.hardContent: Discretionary and support trusts restrict the beneficiary’s ability to demand payments, which in turn restricts creditor access. In a discretionary trust, the trustee has absolute discretion over whether and how much to distribute, so the beneficiary has no right to income until the trustee exercises that discretion; creditors generally cannot reach trust assets, but if they serve the trustee with process, the trustee must satisfy their claims out of any distributions before paying the beneficiary. A support trust directs the trustee to pay only what is necessary for the beneficiary’s support, and creditors typically have the same limited rights as with discretionary trusts. A spendthrift trust includes a clause prohibiting the beneficiary from transferring their trust interest voluntarily or involuntarily, primarily to protect the beneficiary from poor financial decisions; as a result, creditors cannot reach the beneficiary’s trust interest, though they may reach distributions once made. Despite spendthrift or similar restrictions, certain preferred creditors—spousal or child support claimants, providers of basic necessities, and federal or state tax authorities—may reach the trust assets to satisfy their claims.

cards.clozeLite: In {{c1::discretionary trusts}}, the trustee has {{c2::absolute discretion over distributions}}, so {{c3::creditors generally cannot compel payment}}. {{c4::Spendthrift trusts}} bar {{c5::voluntary and involuntary transfers}} of the beneficiary’s interest.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 033. Charitable Trusts
cards.backPlain: A charitable trust is a trust that has the purpose of benefitting an unascertained group of people or the public at large. Key features: - Beneficiaries: Must be a reasonably large, indefinite, and unascertainable class (not specific, identifiable individuals), though a single qualifying charitable organization is allowed. - Charitable purpose: The trust’s purpose must benefit the public. Courts look to the effect of the gift, not the settlor’s motive. Some political-initiative trusts can qualify, but not trusts for a political party. - Perpetuity: The Rule Against Perpetuities does not apply, so charitable trusts can be perpetual. - Modification: If the original purpose fails or becomes impractical, a court may modify the trust and redirect property to a similar charitable purpose under the cy pres doctrine.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a charitable trust, and what are its main features (beneficiaries, public-benefit purpose, perpetuity, and cy pres modification)?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::charitable trust}} is a trust that has the purpose of benefitting an {{c2::unascertained group of people or the public at large}}. Key features: - {{c3::Indefinite, unascertainable beneficiaries}} (not specific, identifiable individuals; a single qualifying charitable organization is allowed). - {{c4::Charitable purpose that benefits the public}}, based on the {{c5::effect of the gift, not the settlor’s motive}}; some {{c6::political-initiative}} trusts qualify, but not those {{c7::favoring a political party}}. - Can be {{c8::perpetual}} because the {{c9::Rule Against Perpetuities does not apply}}. - Can be {{c10::modified under cy pres}} to redirect property to a similar charitable purpose if the original purpose fails or becomes impractical.
cards.easyContent: A charitable trust benefits an unascertained group or the public at large, has a public-benefit charitable purpose, can last perpetually without RAP problems, and can be modified under cy pres if its original purpose fails.
cards.mediumContent: A charitable trust is created to benefit an unascertained, reasonably large class or the public at large. It must have a charitable purpose that benefits the public, judged by the effect of the gift rather than the settlor’s motive. Charitable trusts are exempt from the Rule Against Perpetuities and may be perpetual. If the original charitable purpose becomes impossible, impractical, or wasteful, a court may modify the trust and redirect the assets to a similar charitable purpose under cy pres.
cards.hardContent: A charitable trust is a trust whose purpose is to benefit an unascertained group of people or the public at large. It must be in favor of a reasonably large class of indefinite, unascertainable beneficiaries (not specific, identifiable individuals), although a single qualifying charitable organization is acceptable. The trust’s purpose must be charitable and must benefit the public; courts look to the effect of the gift, not the settlor’s motive. Some trusts supporting political initiatives, including efforts to change the law, can be charitable, but a trust directly favoring a political party is not. Charitable trusts are exempt from the Rule Against Perpetuities and can be perpetual. If the original charitable purpose is accomplished, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful, a court can use the cy pres doctrine to redirect the property to a different, but as near as possible, charitable purpose.
cards.mnemonic: BIG-P: Beneficiaries Indefinite, Gift to Public, Perpetual, cy Pres.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) definition and indefinite beneficiaries, (2) charitable purpose and political initiatives, (3) perpetuity and RAP, (4) cy pres modification.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::charitable trust}} benefits an {{c2::unascertained, reasonably large class}} with a {{c3::public-benefit charitable purpose}}, is {{c4::exempt from RAP}}, and may be {{c5::modified under cy pres}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 034. Termination, Revocation, & Modification
cards.backPlain: Trusts terminate automatically at the expiration of a specified trust term or when their purposes have become accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or contrary to public policy. For private trusts, most states allow modification or revocation by the settlor (unless expressly prohibited) or by the beneficiaries, either with the settlor’s consent or—if all beneficiaries agree—without the settlor’s consent so long as doing so does not frustrate a material purpose of the trust. Issues can arise where there are unborn, unascertained, or minor beneficiaries, and some states appoint representatives for them. For charitable trusts, if the original charitable purpose is accomplished or becomes impractical, unlawful, or wasteful, courts may apply the cy pres doctrine to modify the trust to carry out a purpose as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intention.
cards.frontPrompt: At a high level, when do trusts terminate automatically, how can private trusts be modified or revoked, and how are charitable trusts adjusted under cy pres?
cards.cloze: Trusts terminate automatically at the expiration of a {{c1::specified trust term}} or when their purposes have become {{c2::accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or contrary to public policy}}. In most states, a {{c3::private trust}} is {{c4::revocable or modifiable by the settlor}} unless the trust {{c5::expressly prohibits modification or revocation}}. {{c6::Beneficiaries}} may also seek modification or revocation, either with {{c7::settlor consent}} or, if all agree and it {{c8::does not frustrate a material purpose}}, without settlor consent. For {{c9::charitable trusts}}, courts may apply the {{c10::cy pres doctrine}} to modify the trust when its original charitable purpose is {{c11::accomplished}} or becomes {{c12::impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}, so that the property is applied to a purpose {{c13::as near as possible to the settlor’s charitable intention}}.
cards.easyContent: A trust ends when its term expires or its purpose is fulfilled, illegal, impossible, or against public policy. Private trusts can usually be changed by the settlor (unless the trust forbids it) or by all beneficiaries under certain conditions, and charitable trusts can be redirected under cy pres when their original purpose fails.
cards.mediumContent: Trusts terminate automatically when their set term expires or their purposes are accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or contrary to public policy. In most states, a private trust is revocable or modifiable by the settlor unless the trust expressly makes it irrevocable. Beneficiaries can change or revoke the trust with the consent of the settlor and all beneficiaries, or, without the settlor’s consent, if all beneficiaries agree and the change does not frustrate a material purpose of the trust, though unborn or unascertained beneficiaries complicate unanimous consent (some states appoint representatives). For charitable trusts, courts use cy pres to modify the trust to a purpose as near as possible to the settlor’s charitable intent when the original purpose is accomplished or becomes impractical, unlawful, or wasteful.
cards.hardContent: A trust terminates automatically when its specified term expires or when its purposes have been accomplished, become unlawful or impossible, or are contrary to public policy. For private trusts, in most states the settlor may modify or revoke unless the trust explicitly prohibits such changes. Beneficiaries may modify or revoke with the consent of the settlor and all beneficiaries. Without the settlor’s consent, all beneficiaries may consent to modification or revocation only if it will not frustrate a material purpose of the trust. This requirement extends to unborn or unascertained beneficiaries, which may make unanimous consent impossible; some states respond by appointing a representative for minor, unborn, or unascertained beneficiaries. For charitable trusts, courts may invoke the cy pres doctrine to modify the trust terms so that the property is applied to a charitable purpose as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intention when the original purpose is accomplished or becomes impractical, unlawful, or wasteful.
cards.mnemonic: Trust change: "S + All B's, No Material Purpose"; charities shift by cy pres.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) automatic termination of trusts, (2) settlor revocation/modification rules for private trusts, (3) beneficiary-driven modification/revocation (with and without settlor consent, including unborn/unascertained beneficiaries), and (4) cy pres for charitable trusts.
cards.clozeLite: A trust ends when its {{c1::term expires}} or its purpose is {{c2::accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or against public policy}}. Private trusts are usually {{c3::revocable by the settlor unless made irrevocable}}; beneficiaries may modify or revoke only if {{c4::all beneficiaries consent and no material purpose is frustrated}}. Failed charitable trusts may be modified under {{c5::cy pres}} to a purpose {{c6::as near as possible to the settlor’s charitable intent}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Intestate Share – Spouse + Shared Descendants Only
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 002-1. Intestate Share – Spouse + Shared Descendants Only
cards.front: Intestate Share – Spouse + Shared Descendants Only
cards.frontPrompt: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, what is the surviving spouse’s share when the decedent is survived only by descendants who are also descendants of the spouse, and the spouse has no other descendants?
cards.backPlain: Case 1 (UPC-style intestacy): Decedent is survived by descendants who are also descendants of the surviving spouse, and the surviving spouse has no other descendants (Spouse + shared descendants, and the spouse has no separate issue). Rule: The surviving spouse takes the entire intestate estate.
cards.cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by {{c2::descendants who are also descendants of the surviving spouse}} and the spouse has {{c3::no other descendants}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c4::the entire intestate estate}}.
cards.easyContent: If all of the decedent’s descendants are also the surviving spouse’s, and the spouse has no other children, the spouse takes the whole estate under the UPC.
cards.mediumContent: UPC Case 1: When the only descendants are shared by the decedent and surviving spouse, and the spouse has no separate issue, the surviving spouse inherits 100% of the intestate estate.
cards.hardContent: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy scheme, if the decedent is survived only by descendants who are also descendants of the surviving spouse, and the spouse has no other descendants from outside the relationship, the policy assumes a unified family unit. In this configuration, the surviving spouse receives the entire intestate estate and the children take nothing outright at this stage, expecting to inherit through the spouse.
cards.mnemonic: Shared kids, no extras, spouse sweeps all.
cards.clozeLite: Under UPC {{c1::Case 1}}, when all {{c2::descendants are shared}} and spouse has {{c3::no separate issue}}, the {{c4::surviving spouse takes 100%}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Intestate Share – Spouse + Parent, No Descendants
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 002-2. Intestate Share – Spouse + Parent, No Descendants
cards.front: Intestate Share – Spouse + Parent, No Descendants
cards.frontPrompt: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, what is the surviving spouse’s share when the decedent is survived by a parent but no descendants?
cards.backPlain: Case 2 (UPC-style intestacy): Decedent is survived by a parent but no descendant (Spouse + parent). Rule: The surviving spouse takes $300,000 plus 75% of the remainder of the intestate estate. The remaining 25% of the remainder passes to the decedent’s parent(s).
cards.cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by a {{c2::parent but no descendant}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c3::$300,000}} plus {{c4::75%}} of the {{c5::remaining}} intestate estate, and the balance {{c6::25% of the remainder}} goes to the {{c7::parent(s)}}.
cards.easyContent: If the decedent leaves a spouse and a parent but no descendants, the spouse gets $300,000 plus 75% of the rest; the parent(s) take the remaining 25% of the balance.
cards.mediumContent: UPC Case 2: Where the decedent is survived by a spouse and a parent but no descendants, the spouse’s intestate share is $300,000 plus 75% of the remaining estate. The remaining 25% of the remainder is distributed to the decedent’s surviving parent(s).
cards.hardContent: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, if the decedent leaves a surviving spouse and a parent but no descendants, the legislature protects the spouse as primary beneficiary but still reserves a portion for the prior generation. The spouse receives a $300,000 fixed amount plus 75% of the remaining estate, with the residual 25% of the remainder passing to the decedent’s surviving parent(s). This configuration recognizes both the marital partnership and the continuing interest of the decedent’s parent in the estate.
cards.mnemonic: Spouse + parent: 300k and 3/4; parent 1/4.
cards.clozeLite: If decedent leaves {{c1::spouse and parent but no descendants}}, spouse takes {{c2::$300,000}} plus {{c3::75% of the remaining estate}}, and parents take {{c4::25% of the remainder}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Intestate Share – Spouse + Shared Descendants + Spouse’s Other Issue
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 002-3. Intestate Share – Spouse + Shared Descendants + Spouse’s Other Issue
cards.front: Intestate Share – Spouse + Shared Descendants + Spouse’s Other Issue
cards.frontPrompt: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, what is the surviving spouse’s share when the decedent is survived by descendants who are also descendants of the spouse, and the spouse also has other issue from outside the relationship?
cards.backPlain: Case 3 (UPC-style intestacy): Decedent is survived by descendants who are also descendants of the surviving spouse, and the spouse has other issue (Spouse + shared descendants + spouse’s kids from another relationship). Rule: The surviving spouse takes $225,000 and one-half of the remaining property. Example: Decedent dies owning $375,000 in property. She is survived by her Wife and their daughter, as well as her Wife’s son by an earlier marriage. Under this rule, Wife’s share is $225,000 plus one-half of the $150,000 remainder, for a total of $300,000.
cards.cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by {{c2::descendants who are also descendants of the spouse}} and the spouse has {{c3::other issue from outside the relationship}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c4::$225,000}} plus {{c5::one-half}} of the {{c6::remaining property}}. Example: If the estate is {{c7::$375,000}} and the decedent leaves a spouse, their joint child, and the spouse’s child from a prior relationship, the spouse receives {{c8::$225,000}} + {{c9::½ of the $150,000 remainder}} = {{c10::$300,000}}.
cards.easyContent: If the decedent leaves shared children with the spouse and the spouse also has separate children, the spouse gets $225,000 plus half of the remaining estate under the UPC.
cards.mediumContent: UPC Case 3: Where the decedent’s only descendants are shared with the spouse, but the spouse has additional children from another relationship, the spouse’s intestate share is $225,000 plus one-half of the remaining estate. The other half of the remainder passes to the decedent’s descendants.
cards.hardContent: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, if the decedent is survived by descendants who are also descendants of the spouse, but the spouse has other issue from outside the relationship, the law softens but does not eliminate the spouse’s share. The surviving spouse receives a $225,000 fixed sum plus one-half of the remainder of the estate. The remaining one-half of the remainder passes to the decedent’s descendants. For example, with a $375,000 estate and a surviving spouse, their joint child, and the spouse’s child from another relationship, the spouse receives $225,000 plus half of the $150,000 remainder, totaling $300,000.
cards.mnemonic: Spouse has separate kids: drop to 225k + 1/2 of rest.
cards.clozeLite: UPC: If all decedent’s kids are with spouse but spouse has other kids, spouse gets {{c1::$225,000}} plus {{c2::one-half of the remaining estate}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Intestate Share – Spouse + Decedent’s Non-Spousal Descendants
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 002-4. Intestate Share – Spouse + Decedent’s Non-Spousal Descendants
cards.front: Intestate Share – Spouse + Decedent’s Non-Spousal Descendants
cards.frontPrompt: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, what is the surviving spouse’s share when the decedent is survived by descendants who are not related to the surviving spouse (non-spousal kids)?
cards.backPlain: Case 4 (UPC-style intestacy): Decedent is survived by issue not related to the surviving spouse (Spouse + non-spousal kids). Rule: The surviving spouse takes $150,000 and one-half of the remaining property. The other one-half of the remainder passes to the decedent’s non-spousal descendants.
cards.cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, when the decedent is survived by {{c2::issue not related to the surviving spouse}} (non-spousal kids), the surviving spouse takes {{c3::$150,000}} and {{c4::one-half}} of the {{c5::remaining property}}, with the other {{c6::half of the remainder}} going to the {{c7::decedent’s non-spousal descendants}}.
cards.easyContent: If the decedent’s descendants are not related to the surviving spouse (e.g., the decedent’s prior kids), the spouse gets $150,000 plus half of the remaining estate; the other half of the remainder goes to those descendants.
cards.mediumContent: UPC Case 4: Where the decedent is survived by a spouse and descendants who are not related to the spouse (e.g., children from the decedent’s earlier relationship only), the surviving spouse’s share is $150,000 plus one-half of the remaining estate. The non-spousal descendants receive the other half of the remainder.
cards.hardContent: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, if the decedent leaves a surviving spouse and descendants who are not also descendants of the spouse (non-spousal children), the law balances protection of the spouse against the interests of those prior-line descendants. The surviving spouse receives a $150,000 fixed amount plus one-half of the remaining estate, and the decedent’s non-spousal descendants receive the other half of the remainder.
cards.mnemonic: Non-spousal kids: lowest share—150K plus half.
cards.clozeLite: UPC: spouse + {{c1::non-spousal descendants}} → spouse gets {{c2::$150,000}} plus {{c3::1/2 of the remaining estate}}; {{c4::other 1/2}} to those descendants.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Intestate Share – Spouse Only (No Descendants or Parents)
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 002-5. Intestate Share – Spouse Only (No Descendants or Parents)
cards.front: Intestate Share – Spouse Only (No Descendants or Parents)
cards.frontPrompt: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, what is the surviving spouse’s share when the decedent is not survived by descendants or parents (only a spouse survives)?
cards.backPlain: Case 5 (UPC-style intestacy): Decedent is not survived by descendants or parents (Just spouse). Rule: The surviving spouse takes the entire intestate estate.
cards.cloze: Under a typical {{c1::UPC-style intestacy}} statute, if the decedent is survived only by a {{c2::spouse}} and has {{c3::no descendants or parents}}, the surviving spouse takes {{c4::the entire intestate estate}}.
cards.easyContent: If only the spouse survives—no descendants and no parents—the spouse gets the whole estate under the UPC.
cards.mediumContent: UPC Case 5: Where the decedent dies leaving a spouse but no descendants and no surviving parent, the surviving spouse’s intestate share is 100% of the estate.
cards.hardContent: Under a typical UPC-style intestacy statute, when the decedent is survived solely by a spouse, with no surviving descendants and no surviving parents, the surviving spouse is the exclusive heir and takes the entire intestate estate.
cards.mnemonic: Just spouse, no kin in sight: spouse takes all by right.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UPC, if a decedent leaves {{c1::only a surviving spouse}} and {{c2::no descendants or surviving parents}}, the spouse takes {{c3::100% of the estate}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Intestate Succession – Escheat When No Heirs
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 002-6. Intestate Succession – Escheat When No Heirs
cards.front: Intestate Succession – Escheat When No Heirs
cards.frontPrompt: In intestate succession under a typical UPC-style system, what happens to the property if the decedent dies without any heirs?
cards.backPlain: Escheat When No Heirs: If an intestate decedent leaves no heirs at all—no surviving spouse, descendants, parents, more remote kindred, or other qualifying heirs—then the intestate estate will escheat to the state. Escheat is a default rule ensuring that property does not remain ownerless.
cards.cloze: If an intestate decedent dies with {{c1::no heirs at all}}—no surviving spouse, descendants, parents, or other qualifying relatives—the intestate estate {{c2::escheats to the state}} under a typical UPC-style system. {{c3::Escheat}} is the default rule to prevent property from remaining ownerless.
cards.easyContent: If there are no heirs under intestacy, the estate escheats to the state so the property is not ownerless.
cards.mediumContent: Under UPC-style intestacy, when a decedent dies with no surviving spouse, descendants, parents, or other qualifying heirs, the intestate estate escheats to the state. Escheat is the last-resort rule for property with no private owner.
cards.hardContent: In a UPC-style intestacy framework, if the decedent leaves no qualifying heirs—no spouse, issue, parents, grandparents or their descendants, or other relatives recognized under the statute—the intestate estate does not remain in limbo. Instead, it escheats to the state, meaning title passes to the state as ultimate taker of last resort to prevent property from being ownerless.
cards.mnemonic: NO HEIRS? Think ES-CHEAT: State wins the estate.
cards.clozeLite: If a decedent dies with {{c1::no qualifying heirs}}, the {{c2::intestate estate}} {{c3::escheats to the state}} as {{c4::taker of last resort}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Contracts Involving Wills – Validity and Writing Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 020-1. Contracts Involving Wills – Validity and Writing Requirements
cards.front: Contracts Involving Wills – Validity and Writing Requirements
cards.frontPrompt: How are contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will treated under contract law, and what writing requirements apply (including under the UPC)?
cards.backPlain: 1. Enforceability and contract nature 1.1. Valid contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will are generally enforceable. 1.2. These are governed by ordinary contract law, not will law. 1.3. They are not themselves wills. 1.4. Standard contract requirements must be satisfied (e.g., mutual assent, consideration). 2. Writing requirements (most states) 2.1. Most states require contracts involving wills to be in writing. 3. UPC and similar statutes – how the writing requirement can be satisfied 3.1. The UPC and some states require one of the following: 3.1.1. Provisions in the will stating the material provisions of the contract; OR 3.1.2. An express reference in the will to the contract and extrinsic evidence proving the contract terms; OR 3.1.3. A separate writing signed by the decedent/testator evidencing the contract.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Valid contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will}} are generally {{c2::enforceable}}. 1.1. They are governed by {{c3::ordinary contract law}}, not by will law, and {{c4::are not themselves wills}}. 1.2. They must satisfy {{c5::standard contract requirements}} such as mutual assent and consideration. 2. {{c6::Most states}} require contracts involving wills to be {{c7::in writing}}. 3. Under the {{c8::UPC}} and similar statutes, the writing requirement can be satisfied by one of three alternatives: 3.1. {{c9::Provisions in the will stating the material provisions of the contract}}; OR 3.2. An {{c10::express reference in the will to the contract}} plus {{c11::extrinsic evidence}} proving the contract terms; OR 3.3. A {{c12::separate writing signed by the decedent/testator}} evidencing the contract.
cards.easyContent: Contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will are governed by ordinary contract law, must meet normal contract requirements, and in most states must be in writing, with the UPC listing specific ways to satisfy the writing requirement.
cards.mediumContent: Contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will are enforceable if they satisfy standard contract requirements like mutual assent and consideration and are governed by contract law, not will law. Most states require such contracts to be in writing. Under the UPC, that requirement can be met by: (1) will provisions stating the contract’s material terms; (2) an express reference in the will to the contract plus extrinsic proof of its terms; or (3) a separate writing signed by the decedent evidencing the contract.
cards.hardContent: Valid contracts to make, not make, or revoke a will are treated as ordinary contracts: they are not themselves wills, they are governed by contract law, and they must meet standard contract requirements such as mutual assent and consideration. Most states require these contracts to be in writing. The UPC and similar statutes specify that the writing requirement can be satisfied in one of three ways: (1) the will itself states the material provisions of the contract; (2) the will expressly refers to the contract, and extrinsic evidence establishes its terms; or (3) a separate writing signed by the decedent/testator evidences the contract.
cards.mnemonic: C+W+3W: Contract law, Writing, and 3 UPC Writings.
cards.atomizationNotes: Focuses on enforceability and writing requirements for contracts involving wills.
cards.clozeLite: Contracts to {{c1::make, not make, or revoke a will}} are {{c2::governed by contract law}} and {{c3::usually must be in writing}}. Under the UPC, writing is met by {{c4::will terms, will reference + proof, or a separate signed writing}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Contracts Involving Wills – Remedy for Breach (Constructive Trust)
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 020-2. Contracts Involving Wills – Remedy for Breach (Constructive Trust)
cards.front: Contracts Involving Wills – Remedy for Breach
cards.frontPrompt: What is the usual remedy for breach of a contract to make, not make, or revoke a will, and how is it implemented?
cards.backPlain: 1. Typical remedy 1.1. Constructive trust is the usual remedy for breach of a contract involving a will. 2. Operation of the remedy 2.1. If a testator breaches a contract to make, not make, or revoke a will—e.g., by failing to provide for the contracting party—the court usually: 2.1.1. Admits the will to probate as written; and 2.1.2. Imposes a constructive trust on the property in favor of the intended beneficiary under the contract. 2.2. The constructive trust enforces the contract’s promised disposition in equity, even though the legal title passes under the probated will.
cards.cloze: 1. The usual remedy for breach of a {{c1::contract to make, not make, or revoke a will}} is a {{c2::constructive trust}}. 2. In practice, when a testator breaches such a contract—such as by failing to provide for the contracting party—the court generally: 2.1. {{c3::Admits the will to probate}} as written; and 2.2. {{c4::Imposes a constructive trust}} on the affected property in favor of the {{c5::intended contract beneficiary}}. 3. The constructive trust allows the court in {{c6::equity}} to carry out the promised disposition, even though {{c7::legal title passes under the probated will}}.
cards.easyContent: When a contract to make, not make, or revoke a will is breached, courts usually probate the will as written and then impose a constructive trust on the property for the intended contract beneficiary.
cards.mediumContent: If a testator breaches a valid contract involving a will, the usual remedy is a constructive trust. The court will generally admit the will to probate but then impose a constructive trust on the relevant property in favor of the intended contract beneficiary, using equity to enforce the contractual disposition despite the will’s terms.
cards.hardContent: On breach of a valid contract to make, not make, or revoke a will—for example, when the testator fails to leave property as promised—the principal remedy is equitable: a constructive trust. The court typically admits the will to probate as written, allowing legal title to pass under the will, but then imposes a constructive trust over the affected property in favor of the intended beneficiary under the contract, thereby enforcing the contractual arrangement in equity.
cards.mnemonic: Breach of will-contract? “Probate then Police it” with a constructive trust.
cards.atomizationNotes: Focuses on constructive trust as the usual remedy for breach of a contract involving a will.
cards.clozeLite: If a testator breaches a valid {{c1::contract involving a will}}, the usual remedy is a {{c2::constructive trust}} imposed {{c3::after probating the will as written}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Joint and Mutual Wills – Definitions and Contract Effect
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 020-3. Joint and Mutual Wills – Definitions and Contract Effect
cards.front: Joint and Mutual Wills – Definitions and Contract Effect
cards.frontPrompt: What are joint and mutual wills, how do they differ structurally, and when are they treated as contracts not to revoke?
cards.backPlain: 1. Joint will 1.1. A joint will is the will of two or more people executed in a single document. 1.2. It is admissible to probate upon the death of either testator. 1.3. If one testator revokes the joint will, it remains valid as the other’s will. 1.4. A joint will may be interpreted as a contract for a will—often as a contract not to revoke—particularly if executed pursuant to a promise between each party not to revoke. 2. Mutual will 2.1. Mutual wills are separate wills of two or more people containing reciprocal or substantially similar provisions. 2.2. Mutual wills are usually not interpreted as a contract to make a will or a contract not to revoke; more is needed (e.g., explicit contractual language or separate proof of a contract).
