cards.cloze: 1. A {{c1::joint will}} is the will of {{c2::two or more people}} executed in a {{c3::single document}}. 1.1. It is {{c4::admissible to probate upon the death of either testator}}. 1.2. If one testator {{c5::revokes}} the joint will, it generally remains {{c6::valid as the other’s will}}. 1.3. A joint will may be interpreted as a {{c7::contract for a will}}—often a {{c8::contract not to revoke}}—especially where it is executed pursuant to a {{c9::promise between the parties not to revoke}}. 2. {{c10::Mutual wills}} are {{c11::separate wills}} of two or more people that contain {{c12::reciprocal or substantially similar provisions}}. 2.1. Mutual wills are {{c13::usually not interpreted}} as a {{c14::binding contract}} to make a will or not to revoke; courts generally require {{c15::additional evidence of a contract}} (such as explicit contractual language or separate proof).
cards.easyContent: A joint will is a single document for two or more testators and can sometimes be treated as a contract not to revoke. Mutual wills are separate but similar wills and are usually not treated as a binding contract without more evidence.
cards.mediumContent: A joint will is a single instrument executed by two or more people, admissible to probate on either’s death, and, especially if based on a promise not to revoke, may be construed as a contract for a will or contract not to revoke. Mutual wills are separate wills containing reciprocal or substantially similar provisions. Mutual wills alone are usually not enough to show a binding contract to make or not revoke a will; courts typically require explicit contractual language or other proof of a contract.
cards.hardContent: Joint wills and mutual wills differ both structurally and in their contractual implications. A joint will is the will of two or more testators executed in one document, admissible to probate upon either’s death, and if one revokes it, it normally remains valid as the other’s will. Courts may treat a joint will—especially when executed pursuant to mutual promises not to revoke—as evidence of a contract for a will or contract not to revoke. Mutual wills, in contrast, are separate wills of two or more people containing reciprocal or substantially similar provisions. The mere existence of mutual wills usually does not establish a binding contract to make, not make, or refrain from changing a will; additional indications of contractual intent are typically required.
cards.mnemonic: Joint = one contract-like doc; mutual = many, usually no contract.
cards.atomizationNotes: Focuses on definitions and contractual effect of joint vs. mutual wills.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::joint will}} is one {{c2::single instrument for multiple testators}} and may show a {{c3::contract not to revoke}}; {{c4::mutual wills}} are {{c5::separate reciprocal wills}} and usually do **not** show such a contract alone.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 023-1. Mistake (Wills) – Nature of Instrument
cards.frontPrompt: What is a mistake as to the nature of the instrument in wills, what evidence is admissible, and what is the effect on testamentary intent?
cards.backPlain: 1. Mistake as to nature of instrument 1.1 Definition: A mistake as to the nature of the instrument occurs when the testator is mistaken about what document he is signing—for example, he does not realize that he is signing his will. 1.2 Extrinsic evidence: Courts may admit extrinsic evidence to show that the testator was mistaken as to the nature of the instrument he signed. 1.3 Effect on testamentary intent: If the testator did not know he was signing a will, this mistake may nullify the testamentary intent requirement and the will may be invalid.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Mistake as to nature of instrument}} 1.1 Occurs when the testator is {{c2::mistaken about what document he is signing}} (e.g., does not realize it is his will). 1.2 {{c3::Extrinsic evidence}} is admissible to show the testator was mistaken as to the nature of the instrument. 1.3 This mistake may nullify the {{c4::testamentary intent}} requirement and render the will {{c5::invalid}}.
cards.easyContent: A mistake as to the nature of the instrument happens when the testator doesn’t realize he is signing a will. Extrinsic evidence is allowed to prove this, and if shown, the will fails for lack of testamentary intent.
cards.mediumContent: A mistake as to the nature of the instrument arises when the testator is wrong about what document he is signing, such as not realizing it is his will. Courts allow extrinsic evidence to prove this mistake. If established, the testator lacked testamentary intent, and the purported will is invalid.
cards.hardContent: A mistake as to the nature of the instrument occurs when the testator is mistaken about what he is signing—for example, believing he is signing a non-testamentary document rather than his will. Courts permit the use of extrinsic evidence to show this type of mistake. Because a valid will requires that the testator intend the instrument to be his will, a proven mistake as to the nature of the instrument can nullify the testamentary intent requirement and cause the instrument to fail as a will.
cards.mnemonic: Nature mistake: doesn’t know it’s a will, so no intent.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::mistake as to the nature of the instrument}} occurs when the testator {{c2::doesn't realize he's signing a will}}; {{c3::extrinsic evidence is admissible}}, and the {{c4::will is invalid for lack of testamentary intent}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 023-2. Mistake (Wills) – Mistake in Inducement
cards.frontPrompt: What is a mistake in inducement in wills, is relief available, and when can the will still be contested?
cards.backPlain: 2. Mistake in inducement 2.1 Definition: A mistake in inducement occurs when the testator is mistaken about the reasons or facts that led him to make the will or to make (or not make) a particular gift or omission. 2.2 General rule: No relief is available solely because the testator’s reason for making or omitting a gift was based on a mistake. 2.3 Exception: Relief may be available if there is a separate, independent ground for contesting the will, such as fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of capacity.
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Mistake in inducement}} 2.1 Occurs when the testator is mistaken about the {{c2::reasons or facts that led him to make the will or a particular gift or omission}}. 2.2 {{c3::General rule}}: No relief is available merely because the testator’s motive or reason was mistaken. 2.3 {{c4::Exception}}: Relief may be available if there is a {{c5::separate ground for contesting the will}}, such as {{c6::fraud}}, {{c7::undue influence}}, or {{c8::duress}}.
cards.easyContent: A mistake in inducement happens when the testator is wrong about the reasons or facts motivating a will or gift. Courts generally do not fix the will just because the reason was mistaken, unless there’s another ground like fraud or undue influence.
cards.mediumContent: A mistake in inducement is an error about the facts or reasons that induced the testator to make the will or to include or exclude a particular gift. The usual rule is that courts give no relief merely because the testator’s motive was mistaken. Relief may be available only if there is an independent basis to attack the will, such as fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of capacity.
cards.hardContent: A mistake in inducement occurs where the testator acts under a mistaken belief about facts that lead him to dispose of his property in a particular way—for example, believing a child is dead or estranged when that is not true. Courts typically will not alter or invalidate the will on the basis of this mistaken motive or belief alone. However, the will (or a provision in it) may still be set aside if the mistake in inducement is accompanied by a separate, recognized ground for contesting the will, such as fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of testamentary capacity.
cards.mnemonic: IN DUE? Inducement: No relief, need fraud/undue.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::mistake in inducement}} is a mistaken {{c2::fact or reason motivating a gift}}, and {{c3::no relief}} is given absent {{c4::fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of capacity}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Mistake (Wills) – Mistaken Omission and Extrinsic Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 023-3. Mistake (Wills) – Mistaken Omission and Extrinsic Evidence
cards.front: Mistake (Wills) – Mistaken Omission and Extrinsic Evidence
cards.frontPrompt: How do courts treat alleged mistaken omissions or misstatements in wills, and is extrinsic evidence admissible absent another ground for contest?
cards.backPlain: 3. Mistaken omission or misstatement of intent 3.1 General rule: No relief is available and no extrinsic evidence is admissible solely to show that a will mistakenly omitted a provision or contains provisions that do not reflect the testator’s actual intent. 3.2 Independent grounds: Relief may be available if there is a separate ground for contesting the will (e.g., fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of capacity). In that case, extrinsic evidence may be used in support of that ground.
cards.cloze: 3. {{c1::Mistaken omission or misstatement of intent}} 3.1 {{c2::General rule}}: Courts provide {{c3::no relief}} and admit {{c4::no extrinsic evidence}} just to show that a will {{c5::omitted a provision}} or contains terms that {{c6::do not reflect the testator’s actual intent}}. 3.2 Relief may be available only if there is a {{c7::separate ground for contesting the will}} (e.g., {{c8::fraud}}, {{c9::undue influence}}, {{c10::duress}}, or lack of capacity), in which case extrinsic evidence may be considered for that purpose.
cards.easyContent: If a will supposedly left something out or misstated the testator’s wishes, courts generally won’t admit extrinsic evidence or rewrite the will just to fix that, unless there is another ground like fraud or undue influence.
cards.mediumContent: For alleged mistaken omissions or misstatements, the traditional rule is that courts do not admit extrinsic evidence merely to prove the will omitted a provision or misstates the testator’s intent, and they will not rewrite the will on that basis. Relief is available only if there is an independent ground for contesting the will, such as fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of capacity, in which case extrinsic evidence may be used to prove that ground.
cards.hardContent: When a party claims that a will mistakenly omitted a provision or that a provision as written does not match the testator’s actual intent, courts traditionally apply a strict rule: they do not allow extrinsic evidence solely to show that the written terms are incomplete or inaccurate relative to the testator’s unexpressed wishes, and they do not reform the will on that basis alone. Instead, the written instrument controls. Relief may still be obtained if there is a recognized independent ground for challenging the will, such as fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of testamentary capacity. In those contests, extrinsic evidence is admissible to prove the separate ground for invalidity, but not simply to fill in or correct mistaken omissions.
cards.mnemonic: No FIX unless FUDC: Fraud, Undue influence, Duress, Capacity.
cards.clozeLite: Courts {{c1::won’t admit extrinsic evidence}} just to fix {{c2::mistaken omissions or misstatements}} in a will, {{c3::unless there’s an independent ground}} like {{c4::fraud, undue influence, duress, or lack of capacity}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 023-4. Mistake (Wills) – UPC Reformation and Ambiguities
cards.frontPrompt: Under the UPC, when may a court reform a will for mistake, what is the evidentiary standard, and how are ambiguities treated?
cards.backPlain: 4. Reformation for a mistake under the UPC 4.1 Authority to reform: Under the UPC, a court may reform the terms of a will to conform to the testator's intent. 4.2 Requirements: It must be shown by clear and convincing evidence that a mistake of law or fact affected the will and the testator's intent. 4.3 Ambiguities and extrinsic evidence: Under this approach, both latent and patent ambiguities can be resolved using extrinsic evidence, in order to give effect to the testator’s actual intent.
cards.cloze: 4. {{c1::Reformation for a mistake under the UPC}} 4.1 Under the {{c2::UPC}}, a court may {{c3::reform the terms of a will}} to conform to the {{c4::testator's intent}}. 4.2 This requires {{c5::clear and convincing evidence}} that a {{c6::mistake of law or fact}} affected the {{c7::will’s terms and the testator's intent}}. 4.3 Both {{c8::latent}} and {{c9::patent ambiguities}} may be resolved with {{c10::extrinsic evidence}} to carry out the testator’s actual intent.
cards.easyContent: The UPC lets courts reform a will to match the testator’s intent if there is clear and convincing evidence of a mistake of law or fact, and it lets courts use extrinsic evidence to resolve both latent and patent ambiguities.
cards.mediumContent: Under the UPC, courts have the power to reform the terms of a will so they conform to the testator’s actual intent. To obtain reformation, the proponent must prove by clear and convincing evidence that a mistake of law or fact affected the terms of the will and the testator’s intent. The UPC also allows the use of extrinsic evidence to resolve both latent and patent ambiguities.
cards.hardContent: The UPC adopts a more flexible approach to mistakes in wills by authorizing judicial reformation. A court may reform the terms of a will to make them consistent with the testator’s actual intent, provided the proponent establishes, by clear and convincing evidence, that a mistake of law or fact affected the will’s wording and the testator’s intent. In applying this rule, courts may consider extrinsic evidence beyond the four corners of the document. This includes using extrinsic evidence to resolve both latent ambiguities (where language appears clear but is uncertain in application) and patent ambiguities (where the ambiguity appears on the face of the will), thereby prioritizing intent over strict adherence to the text.
cards.mnemonic: UPC: Use Proof to Correct mistakes and Clarify ambiguities.
cards.clozeLite: Under the UPC, a court may {{c1::reform a will}} upon {{c2::clear and convincing evidence}} of {{c3::mistake of law or fact}}, and may use {{c4::extrinsic evidence}} to resolve {{c5::latent and patent ambiguities}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Trust Basics – Definition, Roles, and Revocability
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 028-1. Trust Basics – Definition, Roles, and Revocability
cards.front: Trust Basics – Definition, Roles, and Revocability
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a trust 1.1 A trust is a fiduciary relationship in which one party (the trustee) holds legal title to property for the benefit of designated beneficiaries, who hold equitable interests. 2. Key parties and roles 2.1 Settlor: The person who creates the trust, transferring legal title to the trustee. 2.2 Trustee: The person or entity who holds legal title and manages, administers, and invests trust property as a fiduciary. 2.3 Beneficiaries: The persons or entities for whose benefit the trust is administered; they hold equitable interests in the trust property. 3. Revocability 3.1 Under modern statutes, trusts are generally revocable unless the trust terms expressly state that the trust is irrevocable. 3.2 A revocable trust allows the settlor to modify or terminate the trust during life; an irrevocable trust generally cannot be altered or revoked once created, absent beneficiary consent and/or court approval under applicable law.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a trust, who are the key parties (settlor, trustee, beneficiaries), and what is the modern default rule on revocability?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of a trust 1.1 A trust is a {{c1::fiduciary relationship}} in which the {{c2::trustee}} holds {{c3::legal title}} to property for the benefit of {{c4::beneficiaries}}, who hold {{c5::equitable interests}}. 2. Key parties and roles 2.1 {{c6::Settlor}}: The person who creates the trust and transfers legal title to the trustee. 2.2 {{c7::Trustee}}: Holds legal title and {{c8::manages and administers}} trust property as a {{c9::fiduciary}}. 2.3 {{c10::Beneficiaries}}: Persons or entities for whose benefit the trust is administered. 3. Revocability 3.1 Under modern statutes, trusts are generally {{c11::revocable}} unless the terms expressly state that the trust is {{c12::irrevocable}}. 3.2 A {{c13::revocable trust}} allows the settlor to {{c14::modify or terminate}} the trust during life; an {{c15::irrevocable trust}} generally cannot be altered or revoked once created, absent appropriate consent or court approval.
cards.easyContent: A trust is a fiduciary relationship where a trustee holds legal title to property for beneficiaries, who hold equitable interests. The settlor creates the trust. Under modern law, trusts are usually revocable unless made irrevocable in the terms.
cards.mediumContent: A trust is a fiduciary relationship in which the trustee holds legal title to property for the benefit of beneficiaries, who have equitable interests. The settlor creates the trust and transfers legal title to the trustee, who manages and administers the property as a fiduciary for the beneficiaries. Under modern statutes, a trust is presumed revocable unless the instrument expressly states it is irrevocable.
cards.hardContent: A trust is a fiduciary relationship whereby the settlor transfers legal title to property to a trustee, who holds and manages it for the benefit of beneficiaries, who hold equitable interests. The trustee owes fiduciary duties in administering and investing trust assets for the beneficiaries’ benefit. Under modern default rules, a trust is generally revocable unless the trust instrument expressly provides that it is irrevocable. In a revocable trust, the settlor retains the power to amend or terminate the trust during life; an irrevocable trust generally cannot be altered or revoked once created, absent beneficiary consent and/or court modification under applicable law.
cards.mnemonic: S-T-B: Settlor creates, Trustee holds, Beneficiaries benefit.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::trust}} is a {{c2::fiduciary relationship}} where the {{c3::trustee holds legal title}} and {{c4::beneficiaries hold equitable interests}}; modern default: {{c5::presumed revocable unless stated irrevocable}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 028-2. Express Trusts – Private and Charitable
cards.backPlain: 1. Express trusts – general 1.1 An express trust is created with the property owner's express intent to create a trust relationship. 1.2 The settlor intentionally transfers property to a trustee to hold for beneficiaries (private) or for charitable purposes (charitable). 2. Private trusts 2.1 A private trust is created for the benefit of certain defined and/or ascertainable persons. 2.2 It is the most commonly tested trust on bar essays. 2.3 A private trust may be created: • Inter vivos (during the settlor's life), often by declaration or trust instrument; or • As a testamentary trust (created by will), taking effect at the settlor's death. 3. Charitable trusts 3.1 A charitable trust is created for the benefit of an indefinite class of people or the public generally. 3.2 The purpose must be charitable in nature (e.g., relief of poverty, advancement of education or religion, promotion of health, or other community benefit). 3.3 Charitable trusts receive special treatment (e.g., no RAP in many jurisdictions, cy pres), but those details are covered in separate cards.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an express trust, and how do private trusts differ from charitable trusts in terms of beneficiaries and purpose?
cards.cloze: 1. Express trusts – general 1.1 An {{c1::express trust}} is created with the property owner's {{c2::express intent}} to create a trust relationship. 2. Private trusts 2.1 A {{c3::private trust}} is created for the benefit of {{c4::defined and/or ascertainable persons}}. 2.2 A private trust may be created {{c5::inter vivos}} (during the settlor's life) or as a {{c6::testamentary trust}} (created by will). 3. Charitable trusts 3.1 A {{c7::charitable trust}} is created for the benefit of an {{c8::indefinite class of people}} or the {{c9::public generally}}. 3.2 The purpose must be {{c10::charitable in nature}} (e.g., {{c11::relief of poverty}}, {{c12::advancement of education or religion}}, {{c13::promotion of health}}, or other {{c14::community benefit}}).
cards.easyContent: Express trusts are intentionally created by the owner. Private trusts benefit defined or ascertainable persons and can be inter vivos or testamentary. Charitable trusts benefit an indefinite class or the public and must serve a charitable purpose.
cards.mediumContent: An express trust arises from the settlor’s express intent to create a trust. Private express trusts are created for defined or ascertainable beneficiaries and are the most commonly tested; they can be created during life (inter vivos) or at death via a testamentary trust in a will. Charitable express trusts are created for an indefinite class or the public and must pursue a charitable purpose, such as relief of poverty, education, religion, health, or other community benefit.
cards.hardContent: An express trust is formed when a property owner, with present, express intent, transfers property to a trustee to hold for the benefit of others or for charitable purposes. A private express trust is created for the benefit of identified or at least ascertainable beneficiaries and is often tested in bar essays; it can be created inter vivos by declaration or transfer, or as a testamentary trust taking effect at the settlor’s death under a will. A charitable express trust, by contrast, is created for an indefinite class or the public generally and must advance a recognized charitable purpose such as relief of poverty, advancement of education or religion, promotion of health, or other community benefit; charitable trusts receive special doctrinal treatment (e.g., relaxed RAP and cy pres) discussed elsewhere.
cards.mnemonic: Express trusts: P-C — Private (persons), Charitable (community).
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::express trust}} arises from the settlor’s {{c2::express intent}} and may be {{c3::private}} (ascertainable beneficiaries) or {{c4::charitable}} (indefinite class/public with {{c5::charitable purpose}}).

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 028-3. Resulting Trusts – Definition and Operation
cards.front: Resulting Trusts – When and Why They Arise
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a resulting trust 1.1 A resulting trust is an equitable trust implied or imposed by law, most often when an express trust fails or does not fully dispose of the trust property. 2. When resulting trusts arise 2.1 Commonly when an express trust fails for some reason, such as: • The intended beneficiary is dead and no alternative is provided; or • The trust terms are void or unenforceable; or • The trust purpose is fully satisfied and surplus remains (in some jurisdictions). 2.2 In such cases, equity presumes that the settlor did not intend the trustee to keep beneficial ownership and implies a resulting trust. 3. Who benefits under a resulting trust 3.1 In a resulting trust, the settlor usually becomes the beneficiary. 3.2 The trustee holds the property in trust and conveys title back to the settlor. 3.3 If the settlor has died, the trustee conveys title to the settlor's estate, and the property is distributed according to the settlor’s will or intestacy.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a resulting trust, in what situations does it typically arise, and who ultimately receives the property?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of a resulting trust 1.1 A {{c1::resulting trust}} is an equitable trust {{c2::implied or imposed by law}}, most often when an {{c3::express trust fails}} or does not fully dispose of the trust property. 2. When resulting trusts arise 2.1 Common triggers include when: • The intended {{c4::beneficiary is dead}} and no substitute is provided. • The trust terms are {{c5::void or unenforceable}}. • The trust purpose is fully {{c6::satisfied}} and surplus remains (in some jurisdictions). 3. Who benefits 3.1 In a resulting trust, the {{c7::settlor}} usually becomes the beneficiary. 3.2 The {{c8::trustee}} holds property in trust and conveys title back to the settlor. 3.3 If the settlor has died, the trustee conveys title to the settlor's {{c9::estate}}.
cards.easyContent: A resulting trust is implied by law when an express trust fails or does not use up the property. The trustee then holds for and returns the property to the settlor, or if the settlor is dead, to the settlor’s estate.
cards.mediumContent: A resulting trust is an equitable trust implied by law when an express trust fails or does not fully dispose of the property, such as when a beneficiary predeceases the settlor without an alternate, the trust terms are void, or the purpose is fully satisfied and money remains. Equity presumes that the settlor did not intend the trustee to take beneficially, so the trustee holds on a resulting trust for the settlor or, if deceased, the settlor’s estate.
cards.hardContent: A resulting trust arises by operation of law when the beneficial interest in property is not fully or effectively disposed of under an express trust. Typical situations include failure of an express trust because the named beneficiary is dead, the trust terms are void or unenforceable, or the trust purpose has been completely fulfilled with surplus remaining. In these circumstances, equity presumes that the settlor did not intend the trustee to retain the beneficial interest. The trustee therefore holds the property on a resulting trust for the settlor, and must convey legal title back to the settlor; if the settlor is deceased, the trustee transfers the property to the settlor's estate, for distribution under the will or intestacy.
cards.mnemonic: Resulting: benefit "results" back to settlor or estate.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::resulting trust}} arises when an {{c2::express trust fails or leaves surplus property}}, and the trustee holds {{c3::for the settlor or the settlor’s estate}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 028-4. Constructive Trusts – Equitable Remedy
cards.backPlain: 1. Nature of a constructive trust 1.1 A constructive trust is not actually a traditional trust consensually created by a settlor. 1.2 Instead, it is an equitable remedy imposed by a court to prevent unjust enrichment. 2. Purpose and operation 2.1 A constructive trust is used to rectify unjust enrichment or wrongful conduct, such as fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, or conversion. 2.2 The court imposes a constructive trust on property in the wrongdoer's possession (or traceable proceeds). 2.3 The wrongdoer is treated as if holding the property in trust for the person who, in equity, should have the benefit. 2.4 The remedy typically requires the wrongdoer to convey legal title to the equitable owner.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a constructive trust, and how does it function as an equitable remedy to prevent unjust enrichment?
cards.cloze: 1. Nature of a constructive trust 1.1 A {{c1::constructive trust}} is not actually a traditional trust, but an {{c2::equitable remedy}} imposed by a court. 2. Purpose and operation 2.1 It is used to prevent {{c3::unjust enrichment}} resulting from {{c4::wrongful conduct}} (e.g., fraud, breach of fiduciary duty). 2.2 The court imposes a constructive trust on property in the {{c5::wrongdoer's possession}} or its {{c6::traceable proceeds}}. 2.3 The wrongdoer is treated as if holding the property {{c7::in trust for the person who should benefit in equity}} and is typically required to {{c8::convey legal title}} to that person.
cards.easyContent: A constructive trust is not a true trust but an equitable remedy. A court imposes it on property held by a wrongdoer to prevent unjust enrichment, treating the wrongdoer as if holding the property in trust for the rightful beneficiary.
cards.mediumContent: A constructive trust is an equitable remedy, not a consensual trust. Courts impose it when someone wrongfully obtains or holds property—through fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, or similar misconduct—to prevent unjust enrichment. The court declares that the wrongdoer holds the property (or its traceable proceeds) in trust for the person who in fairness should have it and orders conveyance of legal title to that person.
cards.hardContent: A constructive trust is an equitable device by which a court treats a person who has wrongfully obtained or retained property—through fraud, duress, undue influence, breach of fiduciary duty, or other wrongful acts—as a trustee for the person who in equity should have the benefit of that property. Unlike express or resulting trusts, it is purely remedial: the court imposes a trust on property in the wrongdoer’s possession (or on identifiable, traceable proceeds) to prevent unjust enrichment and typically compels the transfer of legal title to the equitable owner.
cards.mnemonic: CONSTRUCTIVE: Court CONSTRUCTS a trust to strip unjust gains.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::constructive trust}} is an {{c2::equitable remedy}}, imposed when someone {{c3::wrongfully obtains or holds property}} to prevent {{c4::unjust enrichment}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Charitable Trusts – Definition and Indefinite Beneficiaries
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 033-1. Charitable Trusts – Definition and Indefinite Beneficiaries
cards.backPlain: Definition: - A charitable trust is a trust that has the purpose of benefitting an unascertained group of people or the public at large. Indefinite beneficiaries required: - The trust must be created in favor of a reasonably large class of indefinite beneficiaries. - It cannot be for the benefit of identifiable individuals. - However, a trust benefitting a single charitable organization whose activities meet the charitable requirements is acceptable. - Test: Beneficiaries are indefinite and unascertainable if they are unnamed and changing over time.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a charitable trust, and what are the requirements regarding its beneficiaries?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::charitable trust}} is a trust that has the purpose of benefitting an {{c2::unascertained group of people or the public at large}}. {{c3::Indefinite beneficiaries}} required: - The trust must be created in favor of a {{c4::reasonably large class of indefinite beneficiaries}}. - It cannot be for the benefit of {{c5::identifiable individuals}}. - A trust benefitting a single {{c6::charitable organization}} whose activities meet the charitable requirements is acceptable. - Test: Beneficiaries are indefinite and unascertainable if they are {{c7::unnamed and changing over time}}.
cards.easyContent: A charitable trust is set up to benefit an unascertainable group or the public, not specific named individuals, though it can name a single qualifying charitable organization.
cards.mediumContent: A charitable trust is one whose purpose is to benefit an unascertained group or the public at large. It must favor a reasonably large, indefinite class of beneficiaries, not specific, identifiable individuals, although it may name a single charitable organization as beneficiary if that organization’s activities are charitable. Beneficiaries are indefinite when they are unnamed and changing over time.
cards.hardContent: A charitable trust is a trust whose purpose is to benefit an unascertained group of people or the public at large. It must be created in favor of a reasonably large class of indefinite beneficiaries, and it cannot be structured for the benefit of specific, identifiable individuals. Nevertheless, a trust benefitting a single charitable organization is permissible if that entity’s activities qualify as charitable. Beneficiaries are considered indefinite and unascertainable when they are unnamed and change over time, which reflects the public or broad-class focus of charitable trusts.
cards.mnemonic: Charity serves the "Unnamed and Unnumbered" public.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::charitable trust}} must benefit a {{c2::reasonably large, indefinite class}} of {{c3::unascertained beneficiaries}} or the {{c4::public at large}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Charitable Trusts – Charitable Purpose and Political Initiatives
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 033-2. Charitable Trusts – Charitable Purpose and Political Initiatives
cards.backPlain: Charitable purpose requirement: - The purpose of a charitable trust must be considered to benefit the public. - Courts focus on the effect of the gift, not the settlor's motive. - Example: A trust to build a public swimming pool on land next to the settlor's home is charitable if it benefits the public, even if the settlor’s personal motive is to use the pool. Political initiatives: - A trust for supporting political initiatives can be charitable, including a trust aimed at a present change in law, if it is directed toward a public-benefit objective. - However, a trust in favor of a political party is not a valid charitable trust.
cards.frontPrompt: What is required for a charitable trust’s purpose to be charitable, and how are political-initiative trusts treated?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Charitable purpose}} requirement: - The purpose must be considered to {{c2::benefit the public}}. - Courts look to the {{c3::effect of the gift, not the settlor's motive}}. - Example: A trust to build a public swimming pool next to the settlor’s home is charitable if it {{c4::benefits the public}}, even if the settlor wants personal use. {{c5::Political initiatives}}: - A trust supporting political initiatives, including efforts aimed at a {{c6::present change in law}}, can qualify as charitable if it serves a public benefit. - A trust in favor of a {{c7::political party}} is not a valid charitable trust.
cards.easyContent: A charitable trust must have a purpose that benefits the public, judged by the effect of the gift, not the settlor’s motive. Trusts supporting public-benefit political initiatives (like changing the law) can be charitable, but trusts benefiting a political party are not.
cards.mediumContent: For a trust to be charitable, its purpose must benefit the public, and courts focus on the objective effect of the gift rather than the settlor’s subjective motive. For example, a public pool trust can be charitable even if the settlor wants to use the pool. Trusts that support political initiatives, such as changing the law for public benefit, can qualify as charitable, but a trust that simply benefits a political party is not charitable.
cards.hardContent: The charitable purpose requirement demands that the trust’s purpose be one that benefits the public, not merely specific individuals. Courts assess this by looking to the effect of the gift rather than the settlor's motive; thus, a trust to construct a public facility like a swimming pool may be charitable even if the settlor anticipated personal use. Political-initiative trusts can fall within the charitable category if they are directed toward public-benefit objectives, such as advocating for or implementing a change in law. However, a trust that directly favors or financially supports a political party does not satisfy the charitable purpose requirement and is not a valid charitable trust.
cards.mnemonic: Charity loves Policies, not Parties: public good yes, party no.
cards.clozeLite: A charitable trust must {{c1::benefit the public}}, judged by {{c2::objective effect, not motive}}; {{c3::public-benefit law-change initiatives}} can qualify, but {{c4::party-benefit trusts are not charitable}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 033-3. Charitable Trusts – Perpetuity and RAP
cards.backPlain: Perpetuity and RAP: - Charitable trusts can be perpetual. - The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) does not apply to charitable trusts. - In contrast, private trusts are subject to RAP, and all future interests in a private trust must vest, if at all, within the RAP period.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Rule Against Perpetuities apply to charitable trusts, and how is that different from private trusts?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Charitable trusts}} can be {{c2::perpetual}}. - The {{c3::Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP)}} does {{c4::not apply}} to charitable trusts. - By contrast, {{c5::private trusts}} are subject to RAP, and all interests must {{c6::vest, if at all, within the RAP period}}.
cards.easyContent: Charitable trusts can last forever because the Rule Against Perpetuities does not apply to them, unlike private trusts, which must satisfy RAP.
cards.mediumContent: Charitable trusts are exempt from the Rule Against Perpetuities and may be perpetual. Private trusts, however, are subject to RAP, so all future interests in a private trust must vest, if at all, within the RAP period.
cards.hardContent: Charitable trusts are not subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities and therefore may continue indefinitely; they can be truly perpetual. This contrasts with private trusts, which are constrained by RAP: every contingent or executory interest in a private trust must vest, if at all, within the legally prescribed perpetuities period. The exemption for charitable trusts facilitates long-term public-benefit projects.
cards.mnemonic: Charities live forever: "RAP wraps private trusts, not charitable ones."
cards.clozeLite: Charitable trusts are {{c1::exempt from RAP}} and may be {{c2::perpetual}}, unlike {{c3::private trusts}}, whose {{c4::future interests}} must {{c5::vest within the RAP period}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.topic: Charitable Trusts – Cy Pres and Modification
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 033-4. Charitable Trusts – Cy Pres and Modification
cards.backPlain: Cy pres and modification: - A charitable trust’s property can be applied to different charitable purposes through the cy pres doctrine. - When the original charitable purpose becomes impossible, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful, a court may modify the trust. - Under cy pres ("as near as possible"), the court redirects the trust property to a new charitable purpose that is as close as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intent.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the cy pres doctrine, and how does it allow modification of charitable trusts?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::cy pres}} doctrine, a {{c2::charitable trust’s property}} can be applied to {{c3::different charitable purposes}} when the original purpose becomes {{c4::impossible, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}. - The court modifies the trust to carry out a purpose that is {{c5::as near as possible}} to the settlor’s original charitable intent.
cards.easyContent: If a charitable trust’s original purpose can’t be carried out, a court can use cy pres to redirect the property to a similar charitable purpose that’s as close as possible to what the settlor wanted.
cards.mediumContent: The cy pres doctrine allows a court to modify a charitable trust when its original purpose becomes impossible, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful. Instead of letting the trust fail, the court redirects the property to a new charitable purpose that is as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intent.
cards.hardContent: Cy pres is an equitable doctrine used to preserve charitable trusts whose original purposes can no longer be effectively carried out. When the initial charitable objective has been accomplished, or becomes impossible, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful, a court may reform the trust under cy pres by directing the trust property to a new charitable purpose. The substitute purpose must be as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intent, thereby maintaining the public-benefit character of the trust while adapting to changed circumstances.
cards.mnemonic: Cy pres = court picks closest possible new charity purpose.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::cy pres}}, if a charitable trust’s purpose becomes {{c2::impossible, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}, a court {{c3::redirects the trust to a similar charitable purpose}} as {{c4::near as possible to settlor’s intent}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 034-1. Termination – Automatic Termination of Trusts
cards.backPlain: Trusts terminate automatically in either of two main situations: 1. Expiration of the trust term 1.1 A trust terminates automatically at the expiration of a specified trust term stated in the trust instrument. 2. Failure or completion of trust purpose 2.1 A trust also terminates automatically when its purposes have become: • Accomplished (fully carried out), • Unlawful, • Impossible to achieve, or • Contrary to public policy.
cards.frontPrompt: When does a trust terminate automatically without any action by the settlor or beneficiaries?
cards.cloze: Trusts terminate automatically at the expiration of a {{c1::specified trust term}} or when their purposes have become {{c2::accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or contrary to public policy}}.
cards.easyContent: A trust automatically ends when its stated term runs out, or when its purpose is accomplished, unlawful, impossible, or against public policy.
cards.mediumContent: A trust terminates automatically at the end of its specified term or when its purpose has been accomplished, becomes unlawful or impossible to achieve, or becomes contrary to public policy. No action by the settlor or beneficiaries is required for this automatic termination.
cards.hardContent: A trust will terminate automatically in either of two main circumstances: (1) when the trust’s stated duration expires (i.e., at the expiration of the specified trust term), or (2) when the trust’s purposes have been fully accomplished, have become unlawful to pursue, are impossible to achieve, or are contrary to public policy. In these cases, the trust ends by operation of law, without the need for a separate revocation or modification by the settlor or beneficiaries.
cards.mnemonic: Automatic end when TIME’s up or PURPOSE P-U-I-P: accomplished, unlawful, impossible, policy.
cards.clozeLite: A trust terminates automatically {{c1::at the end of its specified term}} or {{c2::when its purpose is accomplished}}, {{c3::unlawful}}, {{c4::impossible}}, or {{c5::contrary to public policy}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 034-2. Revocation & Modification – By Settlor (Private Trusts)
cards.front: Settlor Revocation & Modification of Private Trusts
cards.backPlain: In most states, a settlor’s power over a private trust is as follows: 1. Default rule: revocable and modifiable 1.1 The settlor can modify or revoke a private trust. 2. Exception: express prohibition 2.1 The settlor’s power to modify or revoke is cut off only if the trust terms expressly prohibit modification or revocation (i.e., the trust is expressly made irrevocable or unmodifiable). 3. Key point 3.1 Unless the instrument clearly states otherwise, assume the settlor retains the power to modify or revoke in most states.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the default rule in most states regarding a settlor’s ability to revoke or modify a private trust, and how can that power be limited?
cards.cloze: In most states, the {{c1::settlor}} of a private trust can {{c2::modify or revoke}} the trust unless the trust terms {{c3::expressly prohibit modification or revocation}} (i.e., make the trust irrevocable or unmodifiable).
cards.easyContent: In most states, a settlor can change or revoke a private trust unless the trust instrument clearly says it’s irrevocable.
cards.mediumContent: For private trusts, the default rule in most states is that the settlor can revoke or modify the trust. This power is lost only if the trust instrument explicitly states that the trust is irrevocable or otherwise expressly prohibits modification or revocation.
cards.hardContent: In most jurisdictions, a private trust is presumed revocable and modifiable by the settlor. The settlor retains the power to modify or revoke the trust unless the trust document expressly provides that the trust is irrevocable or otherwise clearly prohibits modification or revocation. Absent such express language, courts generally assume that the settlor intended to retain the power to alter or terminate the trust.
cards.mnemonic: Default: Settlor Stays in Control—unless it clearly says irrevocable.
cards.clozeLite: For {{c1::private trusts}}, the default in most states is that the {{c2::settlor can revoke or modify}} unless the {{c3::trust instrument expressly makes it irrevocable}}.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 034-3. Revocation & Modification – By Beneficiaries (Private Trusts)
cards.front: Beneficiary Modification & Revocation of Private Trusts
cards.backPlain: Beneficiaries may seek to modify or revoke a private trust in two main ways: 1. With settlor consent 1.1 The beneficiaries can modify or revoke the trust if: • The settlor consents, and • All beneficiaries consent. 2. Without settlor consent 2.1 All beneficiaries can consent to modify or revoke the trust without the settlor’s consent if: • Every beneficiary (including future beneficiaries) agrees, and • The change would not frustrate a material purpose of the trust. 3. Unborn, unascertained, and minor beneficiaries 3.1 The requirement that "all beneficiaries" consent includes unborn or unascertained beneficiaries, which can make unanimous consent impossible. 3.2 Some states respond by allowing appointment of a representative for minor, unborn, or unascertained beneficiaries to give consent on their behalf.
cards.frontPrompt: How can beneficiaries modify or revoke a private trust, both with and without the settlor’s consent, and how do unborn or unascertained beneficiaries affect this?
cards.cloze: Beneficiaries can {{c1::modify or revoke}} a private trust with the {{c2::consent of the settlor and all beneficiaries}}. Without the settlor’s consent, {{c3::all beneficiaries}} may agree to modification or revocation only if it {{c4::does not frustrate a material purpose of the trust}}. The requirement that "all beneficiaries" consent includes {{c5::unborn or unascertained beneficiaries}}, which can make unanimous consent impossible; some states allow appointment of a {{c6::representative for minor, unborn, or unascertained beneficiaries}}.
cards.easyContent: Beneficiaries can change or revoke a private trust if the settlor and all beneficiaries agree. Without the settlor, all beneficiaries (including future ones) must agree, and the change cannot defeat a material purpose of the trust; some states appoint representatives for unborn or minor beneficiaries.
cards.mediumContent: Beneficiaries may modify or revoke a private trust if the settlor and all beneficiaries consent. If the settlor does not consent, all beneficiaries—including future, unborn, or unascertained beneficiaries—must agree, and the change must not frustrate a material purpose of the trust. Because this unanimity can be impossible, some states authorize courts to appoint representatives for minor, unborn, or unascertained beneficiaries.
cards.hardContent: Beneficiaries can obtain modification or revocation of a private trust in two ways. With settlor consent, modification or revocation is permitted if both the settlor and all beneficiaries consent. Without settlor consent, the beneficiaries may still modify or revoke the trust if all beneficiaries—present and future, including unborn or unascertained beneficiaries—agree, and the proposed change will not frustrate a material purpose of the trust. The inclusion of unborn or unascertained beneficiaries often makes unanimous consent difficult or impossible; in response, some states allow the court to appoint a representative to act on behalf of minor, unborn, or unascertained beneficiaries for purposes of giving consent.
cards.mnemonic: "All B’s + No Material Purpose" for beneficiary changes.
cards.clozeLite: Beneficiaries may {{c1::modify or revoke}} a private trust if {{c2::settlor and all beneficiaries consent}}; without settlor consent, {{c3::all beneficiaries, including unborn or unascertained,}} must agree and {{c4::no material purpose}} is frustrated.

cards.subject: Trusts And Estates
cards.rawHeader: Trusts And Estates 034-4. Cy Pres Doctrine – Charitable Trusts
cards.front: Cy Pres Doctrine for Charitable Trusts
cards.backPlain: Cy pres allows courts to modify charitable trusts when the original charitable purpose can no longer be carried out as written. 1. When cy pres applies 1.1 Cy pres may be invoked when a charitable trust’s original purpose is: • Accomplished, • Impractical to continue, • Unlawful, or • Wasteful. 2. Effect of cy pres 2.1 The court may modify the terms of the charitable trust so the property is applied to a charitable purpose as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intention. 3. Goal 3.1 Preserve the settlor’s charitable intent while adapting to changed circumstances so the trust does not fail entirely.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the cy pres doctrine in the context of charitable trusts, when does it apply, and what does it allow a court to do?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::cy pres doctrine}} for {{c2::charitable trusts}}, courts may {{c3::modify the terms of a charitable trust}} so the property is applied to a charitable purpose {{c4::as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intention}} when the original charitable purpose is {{c5::accomplished}} or becomes {{c6::impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}.
cards.easyContent: Cy pres lets a court change a charitable trust so that, when the original purpose is completed, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful, the property goes to a similar charitable purpose close to what the settlor wanted.
cards.mediumContent: The cy pres doctrine applies to charitable trusts when the original charitable purpose has been accomplished or becomes impractical, unlawful, or wasteful. The court then modifies the trust so that the property is used for a charitable purpose as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intention, preventing the trust from failing outright.
cards.hardContent: Cy pres is an equitable doctrine applied to charitable trusts when the original charitable purpose has been fulfilled or can no longer be carried out because it is impractical, unlawful, or wasteful. Rather than allowing the trust to fail, the court modifies the trust terms to redirect the trust property to a charitable purpose that is as near as possible to the settlor’s original charitable intention. This preserves the overall charitable character of the disposition while adapting to changed circumstances.
cards.mnemonic: Cy pres = court picks closest possible new charity.
cards.clozeLite: Cy pres applies when a charitable trust’s {{c1::purpose is fulfilled, impractical, unlawful, or wasteful}}, letting a court {{c2::redirect property to a purpose as near as possible to settlor’s intent}}.
